AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	0	58	108	Iraq's Kurdish region to export oil for first time 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	1	187	381	Iraq's self-ruled Kurdish region will begin exporting crude oil for the first time on June 1, piping up to 90,000 bpd to its neighbours in a landmark step for the area, officials said on Sunday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	2	391	622	Companies chosen by the regional government will pump oil from two Kurdish fields via an Iraqi pipeline to Turkey with the consent of Baghdad in a step that could pave the way to ending bitter domestic feuds over Iraq's oil wealth. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	3	632	815	Initial exports will be around 40,000 barrels per day from the Taq Taq field in the province of Arbil and another 50,000 bpd from the Tawke field in Dohuk, company officials told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	4	825	1059	"Piping of the oil will start Monday morning from the Taq Taq field, pumping it from seven wells," said Mohammed Okotan, director of the Taq Taq project for Turkey's Genel Enerji, which is partnered with Calgary-based Addax Petroleum. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	5	1069	1211	"We will try to reach 60,000 barrels a day by the end of this year," said Okotan, adding that the project aims to double exports in two years. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	6	1221	1270	"The quality of the crude is excellent," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	7	1280	1394	At the Tawke field, northwest of Taq Taq, Norwegian oil firm DNO will also start pumping oil for export on Monday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	8	1404	1543	"We'll start with 50,000 bpd and we'll see how this operation goes and if we can increase it," said DNO director of operations Jon Sargent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	9	1553	1777	Exports from Tawke will link with the Iraq-Turkey main export pipeline at the border town of Fishkhabur, while crude from Taq Taq will be trucked from the capital Arbil before connecting with the Iraq-Turkey export pipeline. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	10	1787	1870	Regional president Massud Barzani will preside over an official ceremony on Monday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	11	1880	2076	Disagreements over oil rights, especially between Baghdad and the Kurdish government, have held up exploitation of much of Iraq's massive reserves as well as long-delayed hydrocarbons legislation. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	12	2086	2212	Terms of the Taq Taq deal are for Baghdad to receive 88 percent of revenues of which the Kurd region will get back 17 percent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	13	2213	2281	Genel Enerji and Addax will share 12 percent, Okotan told reporters. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	14	2291	2453	Executives from DNO refused to provide revenue sharing figures, although one DNO official confided that the terms are quite similar to those in the Taq Taq field. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	15	2463	2660	Baghdad has repeatedly said that it is opposed to Arbil signing its own contracts, a position which Kurdish officials have thumbed their nose at by signings dozens of agreements with foreign firms. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	16	2670	2889	Earlier this month Kurd officials announced an eight billion dollar plan to develop Kurdish gas fields with four European and two United Arab Emirates partners that could later supply the EU's flagship Nabucco pipeline. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	17	2899	3106	Oil minister Hussein al-Shahristani responded by calling the deal illegal, although he has come under heavy criticism for failing to lift the nation's anaemic oil and gas output as crude prices have plunged. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	18	3116	3340	Iraq is in dire need of revenue to rebuild its shattered economy, especially after oil prices tumbled a peak of 147 dollars a barrel last July to a current level just above 60 dollars, putting huge pressure on Iraq's budget. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	19	3350	3429	The nation derives more than 90 percent of its revenues from the energy sector. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	20	3439	3604	Iraq wants pump six million barrels per day, up from its current stated output of around 2.2 million, within the next four to five years as new projects come online. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0197	21	3614	3767	The conflict-ravaged country has the world's third largest proven reserves of oil, with more than 115 billion barrels, behind only Saudi Arabia and Iran. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	0	58	102	Breakaway South Ossetia votes for parliament 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	1	189	378	The rebel Georgian region of South Ossetia voted Sunday in polls expected to secure the grip of its separatist leader nine months after it was the subject of war between Russia and Georgia. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	2	388	603	The local opposition says Eduard Kokoity is seeking to use the elections to forge a loyal parliamentary majority to push through an amendment allowing him to run again for office when his second term lapses in 2011. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	3	613	692	Officials estimated the voter turnout at over 70 percent by 4:00 pm (1300 GMT). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	4	693	790	According to law, the vote is deemed valid if the voter turnout reached 50 percent plus one vote. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	5	800	883	Voting was due to end at 1600 GMT, with the first results expected two hours later. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	6	893	1103	Russia -- which outraged the West by recognising South Ossetia as independent in the wake of the August war with Georgia --- has said South Ossetia should not amend the existing term limits in its constitution.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	18	2246	2372	But despite the slow pace of reconstruction in the republic many praise Kokoity for his leadership during the August conflict. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	19	2382	2560	"Kokoity has done a lot for the people of South Ossetia, he's fought 20 years for this country," Angela Tedeyeva, a 32-year-old kindergarden teacher, said as she cast her ballot. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	20	2570	2641	"If people are happy with him, they will vote for him again," she said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	21	2651	2839	Georgia ridiculed the vote, with the country's reintegration minister Temur Iakobashvili saying the elections were "nothing but clownery, a farce and a redistribution of a criminal power." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	22	2849	2987	Kokoity insists the elections were in strict accordance with law, saying the polls were "a maturity test for the small independent state." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	23	2997	3111	He said the large number of voters at the polling stations was proof that the vote was deemed "genuine" by people. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	24	3121	3287	Eighty-eight polling stations have been set up for the region's 50,000 residents as well as additional sites in Russia for expatriates and refugees from the fighting. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	25	3297	3521	Kokoity's critics are concerned that the high number of polling stations placed in the villages which were used to be populated by ethnic Georgians and which are now nearly empty will be used to falsify the election results. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	26	3531	3750	Kokoity -- who built connections in Moscow working as a trade official for the rebel region when it was known as a highway for smuggling in the early 1990s -- has rejected accusations against him as Georgian propaganda.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	29	4160	4333	Moscow and Tbilisi fought a brief but intense war last August over the region, which had enjoyed de facto independence since the early 1990s thanks to tacit Russian support. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0198	30	4343	4454	Following the conflict Russia formally recognised the region as independent, a move followed only by Nicaragua.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0201	0	58	121	Activists rally in Singapore to demand Aung San Suu Kyi release 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0201	1	198	382	More than 100 people rallied in Singapore late Sunday as part of a regional effort by civil rights groups to press Myanmar's military rulers to release democracy icon Aung San Suu Kyi. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0201	2	392	607	The yellow-clad demonstrators observed a minute of silence and released yellow balloons bearing good wishes for the pro-democracy leader during their gathering at a park designated as Singapore's free-speech corner. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0201	3	617	743	Similar rallies were also held simultaneously in Indonesia, the Philippines, Malaysia, Cambodia and Thailand, organisers said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0201	4	753	938	Aung San Suu Kyi has spent 13 of the last 19 years in detention, mostly at her crumbling lakeside mansion after the junta refused to honour elections won by her political party in 1990. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0201	5	948	1218	The Nobel Peace Prize winner was moved to Yangon's notorious Insein prison and charged on May 14 for allegedly breaching the terms of her house arrest after John Yettaw, 53-year-old Mormon and former US military veteran, swam to her home and stayed there for two nights.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	0	58	97	Israel fumes over US settlement demands 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	1	174	372	Israel refused on Sunday to bow to US calls for a freeze of all settlement activity in the occupied West Bank, as it fumed over the "unfair" demands that have raised tensions between the key allies. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	2	382	621	"I want to say in a crystal clear manner that the current Israeli government will not accept in any fashion that legal settlement activity be frozen," said Transport Minister Yisrael Katz, a close ally of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	3	631	842	The premier also held firm on Israel's controversial blockade of Hamas-run Gaza Strip, warning that the Islamists were rearming and that the ceasefire that ended a 22-day war on January 18 remained very fragile. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	4	852	1079	Netanyahu did not himself address the settlements issue during the weekly cabinet meeting, but Katz's fighting words were echoed by other members of the largely right-wing cabinet, including from its most liberal party, Labour. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	5	1089	1316	A senior Israeli official complained that Washington under President Barack Obama -- who has vowed to pursue Middle East peace talks as part of a changed approach to the region -- was placing unfair demands on the Jewish state. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	6	1326	1454	"The Americans have demanded almost nothing from the Palestinians but are asking Israel to take steps that are a real sacrifice. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	7	1455	1520	These demands are unfair," he told AFP on condition of anonymity. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	8	1530	1578	"The Palestinians are taking a passive approach. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	9	1579	1727	They're not even ready to meet the Israeli side and Abu Mazen (Palestinian president Mahmud Abbas) wants the Americans to do all the work," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	10	1737	1919	Abbas, who met Obama last week 10 days after the US president met Netanyahu, has vowed that that he will not resume talks unless Israel freezes settlements in the occupied West Bank. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	11	1929	2129	The Obama administration has demanded that Israel stop all its activity in the settlements, including so-called natural growth construction that allows for building to accommodate a rising population. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	12	2139	2368	The unusually blunt talk over one of the top stumbling points in the stalled Middle East peace process has raised alarm bells that the new US president could put pressure on Israel as part of his new approach to the Muslim world. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	13	2378	2529	"This is an unjustifiable demand that the government and the public do not accept," said Interior Minister Eli Yishai of the ultra-Orthodox Shas party. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	14	2539	2818	Social Affairs Minister Isaac Herzog of the centre-left Labour party, the most liberal in Netanyahu's government, said that "one has to understand that there are various statuses within the settlements" and "saying that the picture is black and white or write or wrong is wrong." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	15	2828	2946	More than 280,000 Israelis live in settlements dotted throughout the West Bank, which Israel captured in the 1967 war. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	16	2956	3154	Although the international community considers all settlements to be illegal, Israel makes a distinction between those built with the state's blessing and outposts constructed without authorisation. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	17	3164	3285	Netanyahu has said he would dismantle outposts, but that it made "no sense" to ask for a complete freeze of construction. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	18	3295	3448	Israeli officials have also complained that Obama's administration has yet to say it will honour commitments in a letter that then US president George W. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	19	3449	3504	Bush sent to then Israeli premier Ariel Sharon in 2004. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	20	3514	3697	Bush said that given the existence of major settlement blocs in the West Bank it was "unrealistic" to expect Israel to fully withdraw from the territory as part of a final peace deal. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	21	3707	3945	Aside from the settlements, there is stark disagreement between Washington and Israel over creating a Palestinian state, with Obama repeatedly saying he was committed to the principle and Netanyahu so far refusing to endorse it in public. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	22	3955	4122	Obama is due in Saudi Arabia and Egypt this week in a bid to reach out to Muslims and end the deep mistrust of the United States felt across much of the Islamic world. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0202	23	4132	4308	Netanyahu on Sunday also held firm on maintaining the blockade of Gaza, saying that "we do not want to strengthen Hamas" by allowing the Islamist group to rebuild its defences. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	0	58	87	Israeli FM to Russia, Belarus 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	1	164	347	Israeli Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman leaves for his first official visits to Russia and Belarus on Monday to discuss Iran and bilateral issues, his ministry said in a statement. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	2	357	551	In Moscow, Lieberman, a Russian-speaking Soviet emigrant, will meet Russian President Dmitry Medvedev, Prime Minister Vladimir Putin, counterpart Sergei Lavrov and heads of the Jewish community. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	3	561	689	He will discuss "political developments and regional threats with his hosts" as well as bilateral relations, said the statement. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	4	699	860	Topping the agenda for the visit is the issue of Iran's controversial nuclear programme, a "severe geopolitical threat to Israel and the entire region," it said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	5	870	1097	Russia is helping build the first nuclear reactor in the Islamic Republic, which Israel considers its arch-enemy after repeated statements by President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad calling for the Jewish state to be "wiped off the map." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	6	1107	1359	Widely considered to be the Middle East's sole if undeclared nuclear power, Israel along with main ally Washington suspects Iran of trying to develop atomic weapons under the guise of a civilian nuclear programme, a charge Tehran has repeatedly denied. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	7	1369	1596	Moscow is seeking a greater role in the Middle East and a Russian foreign ministry spokesman said on Friday that Russia hopes Lieberman's visit will boost the country's hopes of hosting a Middle East peace conference this year. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	8	1606	1727	The statement from Lieberman's ministry made no mention of the conference idea but Israel has so far been unenthusiastic. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	9	1737	1906	Israel is unhappy about Russia's contacts with the Islamist Hamas movement ruling the Gaza Strip, an Iranian-backed group pledged to the destruction of the Jewish state. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	10	1916	2130	Russia is the only member of the Quartet -- the European Union, the United Nations and the United States -- to be formally on speaking terms with Hamas, classified as a terrorist group by the EU, Israel and the US. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	11	2140	2364	During his trip to Damascus a week ago, Lavrov met with Hamas supremo Khaled Meshaal, telling the Vesti-24 channel later that "we felt a more realistic assessment of the situation" following the talks with the exiled leader. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	12	2374	2590	Lavrov also reiterated that Moscow wanted to see Israel lift a blockade it slapped on Gaza after Hamas assumed power there in June 2007, saying "we hope that we can push toward its removal in the foreseeable future." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	13	2600	2681	At the time, Israel said it was said it was "deeply disappointed" by the meeting. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	14	2691	2862	Following his stay in Russia, Lieberman will travel to Belarus where he will meet President Alexander Lukashenko and Foreign Minister Sergei Martynov on Thursday in Minsk. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	15	2872	3072	It will mark Lieberman's first trip to Russia or Belarus since he was sworn in as foreign minister along with the rest of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's largely right-wing government on March 31. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0203	16	3082	3140	Lieberman emigrated from Soviet Moldova to Israel in 1978.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	2	401	567	Third seed Murray became only the third British man in the Open era to reach the last eight here with a convincing 7-5, 7-6 (7/4), 6-1 win over Croatia's Marin Cilic. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	3	577	860	The ever-improving 22-year-old, with former two-time Roland Garros finalist Alex Corretja helping hone his claycourt game, looked in impressive physical condition with a series of long, punishing rallies eventually telling on the 13th seeded Cilic, the youngest man left in the draw. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	4	870	1038	Cilic, who came into the fourth round having lost the fewest number of games of any player in the last 16, was wilting by the time he slipped 0-3 down in the third set. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	5	1048	1181	He needed treatment on his left leg after falling awkwardly before Murray went on to secure a convincing victory in the seventh game. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	6	1191	1300	Chilean 13th seed Gonzalez revealed how an injury signing autographs almost shattered his French Open dreams. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	7	1310	1536	The 28-year-old, who outgunned Romania's Victor Hanescu 6-2, 6-4, 6-2 to reach the Roland Garros quarter-finals for the third time, injured his ankle while signing photos and tennis balls for fans at the Rome Masters in April. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	8	1546	1593	As a result, he spent a month on the sidelines. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	9	1603	1748	"I was signing autographs and someone called me from the other side of the court and when I ran over to them, I twisted my ankle," said Gonzalez. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	10	1758	1872	"I think I only managed to sign two and then I had to go back to the locker room because my ankle was so painful." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	11	1882	2000	The freak accident meant Gonzalez had to skip the rest of the claycourt season to recover in time for the French Open. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	12	2010	2114	But despite the Rome scare, he believes he is now playing some of the best tennis of his 10-year career. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	13	2124	2304	"I think on average I am playing my best," said Gonzalez who made the semi- finals in Rome where he was defeated by Rafael Nadal before being completely finished off by his injury. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	14	2314	2367	"I have played at a good level almost in every match. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	15	2368	2496	I enjoy going onto the courts and into practice although as I am getting older I tend to practice less but with more intensity."

AFP_ENG_20090531.0204	17	2638	2709	Nadal beat Soderling for the loss off just one game in Rome last month.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	0	58	105	Rights group slams Niger's 'institutional coup' 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	1	178	377	African rights campaigners on Sunday condemned Niger's president Mamadou Tandja over his planned referendum on whether to extending his legal term of office, describing it as "an institutional coup". 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	2	387	608	The international community should put pressure on the president and if necessary apply sanctions, said Alioune Tine, head of African Defence for Human Rights (RADDHO) in comments broadcast on Radio France Internationale. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	3	618	669	"In fact this is an institutional coup," said Tine. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	4	670	751	"This is the start of a new chapter of political instability in Niger," he added. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	5	761	860	"The international community needs to react, as in all coups, initially by negotiating," said Tine. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	6	870	937	"And if he (Tandja) does not accept, sanctions need to be imposed." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	7	947	1161	In a broadcast address to the nation on Friday night, Tandja, 71, said he planned to go ahead with a referendum on a new constitution enabling him to stay in power after the normal end of his second five-year term. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	8	1171	1293	He spoke only days after the country's highest court, the Constitutional Court, ruled against such a referendum on Monday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	9	1303	1494	Article 49 of the current constitution, which authorises the president to call a referendum on certain issues, could not serve as a basis for changing the constitution, it said in its ruling. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0208	10	1504	1565	The day after the court's ruling Tandja dissolved parliament.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0214	3	516	733	Ever-improving Murray, 22, has now won four successive matches on clay for the first time in his career and he looked impressive on Sunday with his physical fitness proving crucial in a tie of long, punishing rallies. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0214	4	743	968	He broke Cilic, whom he had beaten twice in their two previous meetings, in the opening game and although the tall Croatian hit back immediately, Murray nipped ahead again in the 11th game on his way to taking the opener 7-5.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0214	6	1115	1351	Murray was soon a break to the good in the third set against the 20-year-old Cilic, the youngest player left in the men's draw, whose miserable afternoon got worse when he needed treatment to his left leg at 0-3 after falling awkwardly.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	0	58	100	Europe's desperate bid to bring out voters 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	1	176	369	European leaders on Sunday stepped up a desperate battle to persuade people to vote for the EU parliament this week, but the campaign has opened up new political divisions across the continent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	2	379	622	With polls indicating a record low turnout for the June 4-7 election, French President Nicolas Sarkozy and German Chancellor Angela Merkel issued a joint plea to voters, saying a strong parliament was essential to confront the economic crisis. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	3	632	855	The two leaders said they want "a strong Europe that protects" its people and called for "all Europeans to vote" in the statement, published by the Journal du Dimanche newspaper in France and Die Welt am Sonntag in Germany. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	4	865	1030	A "strong Europe does not necessarily mean more powers for the European Union, even more European legislation or even more financial means," said Merkel and Sarkozy. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	5	1040	1228	First steps "to assure real European regulation in the financial sector, based on coordination and cooperation between regulators" should be taken at the next EU summit in June, they said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	6	1238	1361	"For speculative funds, tax havens, payment for executives and financial traders, we want an exemplary Europe," they added. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	7	1371	1540	The pair also gave strong backing to the Lisbon reform treaty, intended to streamline EU decision-making but deadlocked by Ireland's rejection in a referendum last year. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	8	1550	1596	"Europe must play a leading role in the world. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	9	1597	1643	For that, it must have efficient institutions. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	10	1644	1694	That is why we need the Lisbon Treaty," they said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	11	1704	1803	Merkel and Sarkozy also reaffirmed opposition to Turkey joining the EU, without naming the country. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	12	1804	1847	"To be able to act, the EU needs frontiers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	13	1848	1887	Unlimited enlargement is not possible." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	14	1897	2118	The joint statement highlighted fears that the vote for the 736 member European assembly could prove a new embarrassment for the 27-nation European Union, after a record 45 percent abstention at the last election in 2004. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	15	2128	2261	In France, a poll for the Le Parisien newspaper Sunday suggested that 55 percent of the nation's would not bother going to the polls. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	16	2262	2360	In Britain, Poland and Romania, fewer than one in three plan to vote, according to recent surveys. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	17	2370	2494	In Spain, which has benefited enormously from EU development funds, political analysts expect turnout of 40 percent at best. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	18	2495	2537	Portugal expects a record abstention rate. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	19	2547	2767	The stakes are higher now, however, as the European Parliament -- the only directly elected EU institution -- will have a bigger voice in decisions that affect 500 million Europeans if the Lisbon treaty comes into force. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	20	2777	2945	"A lot of voters don't understand what the European Parliament does," said Philip White, senior research fellow at the Centre for European Reform think- tank in London. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	21	2955	3020	"You're not voting to keep a government in office or kick it out. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	22	3021	3102	The stakes can seem a little bit less clear than they are in national elections." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	23	3112	3314	But in many countries the EU vote will be a test of the national governments in power, with far-right and left-wing parties expected to benefit from protest votes and low turnouts in some member states. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	24	3324	3591	In Britain, where euroscepticism runs deep, the governing Labour Party is expected to garner only 16 to 17 percent of the vote, putting it in third place against the rival Conservatives and Liberal Democrats, weekend polls in the Times and Sunday Telegraph suggested. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	25	3601	3845	Turnout at European elections in Britain is usually low -- in the last polls in 2004, it was just 38 percent, and this time, fringe parties like the anti-EU UK Independence Party and the far-right British National Party are expected to benefit. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	26	3855	4040	An Economist magazine/YouGov poll last week found that only 31 percent of Britons think its membership of the European Union is a good thing, compared to 37 percent who think it is bad. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	27	4050	4345	The leader of the main opposition Conservatives, David Cameron, has opened up new divisions in Europe by saying he would withdraw his party from the main centre-right bloc in the EU parliament, the European People's Party (EPP), and join a new eurosceptic alliance with Czech and Polish parties. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	28	4355	4531	The EPP is still expected to remain the biggest single party in the parliament, which already has a key role approving the EU budget and passing laws on a wide range of issues. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	29	4541	4663	The parliament will also endorse the new president of the European Commission after a nomination is made by the EU summit. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0216	30	4664	4776	Jose Manuel Barroso, the conservative former Portuguese prime minister, is widely expected to get a second term.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	1	187	339	Iraq's self-ruled Kurdish region will begin exporting crude oil for the first time on Monday, piping up to 90,000 bpd to its neighbours, officials said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	2	349	580	Companies chosen by the regional government will pump oil from two Kurdish fields via an Iraqi pipeline to Turkey with the consent of Baghdad in a step that could pave the way to ending bitter domestic feuds over Iraq's oil wealth. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	3	590	773	Initial exports will be around 40,000 barrels per day from the Taq Taq field in the province of Arbil and another 50,000 bpd from the Tawke field in Dohuk, company officials told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	4	783	1017	"Piping of the oil will start Monday morning from the Taq Taq field, pumping it from seven wells," said Mohammed Okotan, director of the Taq Taq project for Turkey's Genel Enerji, which is partnered with Calgary-based Addax Petroleum. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	5	1027	1169	"We will try to reach 60,000 barrels a day by the end of this year," said Okotan, adding that the project aims to double exports in two years. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	6	1179	1228	"The quality of the crude is excellent," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	7	1238	1352	At the Tawke field, northwest of Taq Taq, Norwegian oil firm DNO will also start pumping oil for export on Monday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	8	1362	1501	"We'll start with 50,000 bpd and we'll see how this operation goes and if we can increase it," said DNO director of operations Jon Sargent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	9	1511	1707	Disagreements over oil rights, especially between Baghdad and the Kurdish government, have held up exploitation of much of Iraq's massive reserves as well as long-delayed hydrocarbons legislation. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	10	1717	1844	Terms of the Taq Taq deal are for Baghdad to receive 88 percent of revenues. of which the Kurd region will get back 17 percent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	11	1845	1913	Genel Enerji and Addax will share 12 percent, Okotan told reporters. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	12	1923	2083	Executives from DNO refused to provide revenue sharing figures, although one DNO official confided that the terms are quite similar to those in the Tawke field. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	13	2093	2319	Iraq is in dire need of revenue to rebuild its shattered economy, especially after oil prices fell from a peak of 147 dollars a barrel last July to a current level just above 60 dollars, putting huge pressure on Iraq's budget. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	14	2329	2408	The nation derives more than 90 percent of its revenues from the energy sector. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	15	2418	2597	Iraq hopes to be able to pump six million barrels per day, up from its current stated output of around 2.2 million, within the next four to five years as new projects come online. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0243	16	2607	2760	The conflict-ravaged country has the world's third largest proven reserves of oil, with more than 115 billion barrels, behind only Saudi Arabia and Iran.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0254	6	954	1136	Szavay, who stunned Venus Williams in the third round, steadied the ship in the fifth game but by that time the first set was out of her reach, Cibulkova taking it 6-2 in 38 minutes. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0254	7	1146	1321	It was a different story at the start of the second half with Cibulkova tightening up and dropping serve to go 0-2 down, but she snatched one back in the next to level at 2-2. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0254	8	1331	1540	The 20th seed then broke again in the fifth game keeping up a steady stream of baseline groundstrokes and allowing Szavay to make the errors as she sought a solution to her opponent's dominance of the rallies.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0254	10	1683	1819	But a wild forehand let that slip away and she followed up with a double fault at break point to hand her opponent an unlikely lifeline. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0254	11	1829	2087	Szavay staved off another match point on her own serve by coming into the net more often, but Cibulkova this time held steady on her own service game to set up a quarter-final tie against either former world No. 1 Maria Sharapova of Russia or Li Na of China.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0280	2	375	575	The elections are seen as a test of the ability of the Croatia's governing coalition to handle the effects of the global economic crisis, which sent the Adriatic country into recession late last year. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0280	3	585	664	Some four million voters were eligible to elect 221 mayors and municipal heads. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0280	4	674	743	Polling stations opened at 0500 GMT and were to close 12 hours later. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0280	5	744	788	First results were expected later on Sunday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0280	6	798	903	At 0900 GMT, four hours after voting started, turnout was at 10.8 percent, the electoral commission said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0280	7	904	986	It was some three percent lower than in the first round voting held two weeks ago. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0280	8	996	1181	In Zagreb, incumbent mayor Milan Bandic of the opposition Social Democrats (SDP) is being tipped to see off a challenge from independent candidate Josip Kregar and win a fourth mandate. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0280	9	1191	1387	On May 17, Prime Minister Ivo Sanader's ruling conservative Croatian Democratic Union (HDZ) was re-elected in most counties in the first round while the SDP asserted their control in major cities. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0280	10	1397	1510	The HDZ and its coalition partners won seven prefect posts and held a majority in 14 out of 21 county assemblies. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0280	11	1511	1590	The SDP got four county prefects and secured control of five county assemblies. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0280	12	1600	1759	The conservatives lost the mayoral post in the country's second biggest town of Split, on the Adriatic coast, where an SDP candidate is to face an independent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0280	13	1769	1990	Local analysts said the vote confirmed that the SDP and left bloc dominate in more developed parts of Croatia as well as in cities, while the HDZ and right- wing parties are more popular in less developed and rural areas. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0280	14	2000	2187	The polls give voters the right for the first time to directly elect mayors, county prefects and municipal heads, along with 21 county assemblies and more than 550 city and town councils. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0280	15	2197	2315	The HDZ, founded by late nationalist leader Franjo Tudjman, returned to power in 2003 after three years in opposition. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0280	16	2316	2499	Sanader has since shaken off the HDZ's hardline nationalist legacy and transformed it into a party that is aiming to lead Croatia to becoming the European Union's 28th member by 2011.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0289	0	58	88	Israel stages 'doomsday' drill 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0289	1	165	336	Israel began its largest-ever exercise on Sunday to test the response of emergency services to a "doomsday" mix of missile attacks, suicide bombings and natural disasters. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0289	2	346	492	The five-day exercise will simulate simultaneous rocket strikes from the Gaza Strip and Lebanon and missile attacks from arch-foes Syria and Iran. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0289	3	502	713	"The mere fact that Israel is preparing with such an exercise improves our ability to better protect our citizens and ultimately lowers the threat," Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said at the cabinet meeting. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0289	4	723	889	During the drill, Israel will be staging a "doomsday scenario" of simultaneous strikes against the country, defence ministry spokesman Shlomo Dror told AFP last week. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0289	5	899	1048	This will include conventional, chemical and biological strikes, as well as a wave of Palestinian suicide bombings, against large population centres. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0289	6	1058	1275	Exercise Turning Point 3 will also simulate the conduct of rescue and medical services during earthquakes and epidemics and will involve the participation of schools, government ministers and other state institutions. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0289	7	1285	1493	The drill's main activity will come on Tuesday, when air-raid sirens sound across the country and citizens must scramble to shelters, in some areas within seconds and others within no more than three minutes. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0289	8	1503	1624	There will also be simulated cabinet meetings in which ministers will weigh their response to such attacks and scenarios. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0289	9	1634	1815	"Schools, kindergartens and educational institutions across Israel will participate in the exercise, practising emergency entry into protected spaces," the army said in a statement. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0289	10	1816	1903	"Rear military bases, governmental offices and public institutions will also practice." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0289	11	1913	2032	It is the third consecutive year Israel is conducting such an exercise, although this year's drill is the largest-ever. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0289	12	2042	2155	"It is an important exercise and it is good that it is happening at this time," Defence Minister Ehud Barak said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0289	13	2165	2373	The manoeuvres were first held in the aftermath of the July-August 2006 war with Lebanon's Hezbollah militia, which revealed major weaknesses in how the Jewish state's homefront dealt with the rocket attacks. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0289	14	2383	2538	"The Second Lebanon War revealed that the homefront was not well prepared for war and citizens found it hard to adapt to the special situation," Dror said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0289	15	2548	2736	Deputy Defence Minister Matan Vilnai told army radio on Sunday that "our enemies think that the rear is our weak point, we have to reinforce this front and be ready to face any situation." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0289	16	2746	2922	The drill comes just two weeks after the air force wrapped up a massive four-day exercise that tested its ability to defend against missile and jet strikes from Syria and Iran. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0289	17	2932	3064	It was the first time the army has simulated strikes from the Islamic republic, located more than 1,000 kilometres (620 miles) away. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0289	18	3074	3278	Israel considers Iran its biggest threat and is a leading campaigner against its nuclear programme, which it suspects is a cover for ambitions to build atomic weapons, charges vehemently denied by Tehran.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0291	2	395	622	The global economic crisis has hit the US industry hard, prompting massive intervention by President Barack Obama's administration to prevent total collapse and a new blow to the nation's economy, which is already in recession.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0292	1	177	346	Turks covet religion and are deeply suspicious of the West, but believe radical Islam poses threats to their country and the world, according to a poll published Sunday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0292	2	356	544	An overwhelming majority of poll respondents -- 76 and 86 percent respectively -- believe the European Union and the United States aim to divide their country, Milliyet newspaper reported. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0292	3	554	644	Turkey is seeking to join the EU and the United States is among the country's NATO allies. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0292	4	654	875	The survey, conducted by Istanbul's Bahcesehir University among 1,715 people in April and May, found that 62 percent see religion as their top value, followed by secularism and democracy at 16 and 13 percent respectively.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0292	8	1345	1527	The poll found that 64 percent do not wish to live next door to a Jew, 52 percent to a Christian, 42 percent to an American and 26 percent to anyone of a different ethnicity or race.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0292	11	1846	1931	About 80 percent said "anti-democratic actions and thoughts" are a threat for Turkey.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	10	1570	1723	Blanc, who suggested it would be very difficult to replicate Lyon's long run of titles, said rigorous hard work in training over the winter had been key.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	13	1921	2045	And mentally we were very strong - several times we turned things around right at the death when things weren't going well."

AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	16	2451	2664	By April, Lyon were fading, their confidence dented by yet another failure to impress in Europe as Barcelona dumped them easily in the Champions League second phase, leaving Bordeaux and Marseille to scrap it out. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	17	2674	2930	Lyon then ultimately did Bordeaux a decisive favour with a May 17 win at Marseille's seething Stade Velodrome to prepare the coronation which came with Saturday's denouement, Yoan Gouffran securing the title after a club record 11th consecutive league win. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	18	2940	3177	Gilding Bordeaux's lily was a League Cup win in April while a further bonus was last week's signing up of star playmaker Yoann Gourcuff, who had only been on loan from AC Milan and who has been the French league's shining star this term. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0293	19	3187	3328	But now they will be judged on whether they can do what Lyon have consistently failed to do - make a good impression in the Champions League.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0294	2	370	623	The ruling said faith-based educational institutions had the right to refuse admission to students who did not meet religious standards, as "maintaining hair unshorn is an essential component of the Sikh religion," according to the Press Trust of India.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0294	5	962	1108	Sikhism requires men and women to keep their hair uncut at all times, and many men sport lengthy beards and wear turbans to cover their long hair. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0294	6	1118	1253	Kaur's petition was supported by male students who had also been refused admission to the university because they trimmed their beards.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0294	10	1762	1872	About 24 million people follow the Sikh faith in India, with a majority of them living in the state of Punjab.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	0	58	100	Europe's desperate bid to bring out voters 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	1	176	369	European leaders on Sunday stepped up a desperate battle to persuade people to vote for the EU parliament this week, but the campaign has opened up new political divisions across the continent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	2	379	622	With polls indicating a record low turnout for the June 4-7 election, French President Nicolas Sarkozy and German Chancellor Angela Merkel issued a joint plea to voters, saying a strong parliament was essential to confront the economic crisis. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	3	632	855	The two leaders said they want "a strong Europe that protects" its people and called for "all Europeans to vote" in the statement, published by the Journal du Dimanche newspaper in France and Die Welt am Sonntag in Germany. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	4	865	1030	A "strong Europe does not necessarily mean more powers for the European Union, even more European legislation or even more financial means," said Merkel and Sarkozy. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	5	1040	1228	First steps "to assure real European regulation in the financial sector, based on coordination and cooperation between regulators" should be taken at the next EU summit in June, they said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	6	1238	1361	"For speculative funds, tax havens, payment for executives and financial traders, we want an exemplary Europe," they added.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	17	2370	2494	In Spain, which has benefited enormously from EU development funds, political analysts expect turnout of 40 percent at best. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	18	2495	2537	Portugal expects a record abstention rate. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	19	2547	2767	The stakes are higher now, however, as the European Parliament -- the only directly elected EU institution -- will have a bigger voice in decisions that affect 500 million Europeans if the Lisbon treaty comes into force. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	20	2777	2945	"A lot of voters don't understand what the European Parliament does," said Philip White, senior research fellow at the Centre for European Reform think- tank in London. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	21	2955	3020	"You're not voting to keep a government in office or kick it out. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	22	3021	3102	The stakes can seem a little bit less clear than they are in national elections." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	23	3112	3314	But in many countries the EU vote will be a test of the national governments in power, with far-right and left-wing parties expected to benefit from protest votes and low turnouts in some member states. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0307	24	3324	3591	In Britain, where euroscepticism runs deep, the governing Labour Party is expected to garner only 16 to 17 percent of the vote, putting it in third place against the rival Conservatives and Liberal Democrats, weekend polls in the Times and Sunday Telegraph suggested.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0312	13	1987	2298	"We believe this risks undercutting Niger's hard won social, political, and economic gains of the past decade, and would be a set-back for democracy, based on the regular, peaceful transition of political power and faithful adherence to constitutional due-process," said US State Department spokesman Ian Kelly.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	0	58	120	French physicists claim breakthrough in ultra-fast data access 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	1	193	400	French physicists said on Sunday they had used ultra-fast lasers that could accelerate storage and retrieval of data on hard discs by up to 100,000 times, pointing the way to a new generation of IT wizardry. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	2	410	610	The research builds on achievements that earned the 2007 Nobel physics prize for Albert Fert of France and Peter Gruenberg of Germany, who ushered in a revolution in miniaturised storage in the 1990s. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	3	620	721	Fert and Gruenberg discovered that tiny changes in magnetic fields can yield a large electric output. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	4	731	881	These differences in turn cause changes in the current in the readout head that scans a hard disk to spot the ones and zeroes in which data is stored. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	5	891	1106	That discovery opened the way to "spintronics", a form of electronics that uses not only electrical charge but also the spin of electrons in individual atoms to provide a more compact, denser storage on hard drives. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	6	1116	1228	But reading and writing data through spintronics has been hampered by the relative slowness of magnetic sensors. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	7	1238	1532	In a study published in the specialist journal Nature Physics, a team led by Jean-Yves Bigot of the Institute of Materials Physics and Chemistry in Strasbourg employed a "femtosecond" laser, using ultra-fast bursts of laser light, to alter electron spin and thus speed up retrieval and storage. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	8	1542	1724	"Our method is called the photonics of spin, because it is photons [particles of light] that modify the state of the electrons' magnetisation" on the storage surface, Bigot told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	9	1734	1832	Data is retrieved with a burst that lasts just a millionth of a billionth of a second, said Bigot. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	10	1842	2013	Femtosecond lasers currently measure around 30 centimetres (12 inches) by 10 centimetres (four inches) which means they are too big for consumer electronics, he cautioned. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	11	2023	2117	Bigot added, though, that their miniaturisation is likely to be achieved over the next decade. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0315	12	2127	2218	IBM, Hitachi and other corporations are "extremely interested" by the research, Bigot said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	0	58	99	First genes spotted for testicular cancer 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	1	172	348	Scientists in Britain said Sunday they had found the first genes that are associated with testicular cancer, the commonest form of cancer for men between the ages of 15 and 45. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	2	358	573	Telltale variants in chromosomes 5, 6 and 12 are linked with an increased risk of the disease, according to their study, which compared the genetic code of 730 men who had testicular cancer with that of healthy men. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	3	583	706	Inheriting the basket of three factors boosts the risk of the cancer, called testicular gem cell tumour, by up to fourfold. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	4	716	777	The study is published online in the journal Nature Genetics. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	5	787	1097	"We have known for some time that men whose father, brothers or sons had testicular cancer are much more likely to get it themselves and we have been searching for this genetic link," said one of the investigators, Elizabeth Rapley of the Institute of Cancer Research, in the southern English county of Surrey. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	6	1107	1211	"We believe there are more (risk factors) still to be found and we are working on identifying the rest." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	7	1221	1328	The three telltales lie near genes that nurture testicular cells which are precursors in sperm development. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	8	1338	1516	Worldwide incidence of testicular cancer is 7.5 cases per 100,000 men, but the rates vary remarkably between countries and according to ancestry, the ICR said in a press release. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	9	1526	1552	Why this is so is unclear. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	10	1553	1657	Inheritance, though, is a well-known risk factor and seems to be far higher than for other cancer types. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	11	1667	1867	Studies have found that the risk to brothers of testicular cancer patients is eight to 10 times higher than the general population, while for fathers of patients, the risk is four to six times higher. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0316	12	1877	1961	Testicular cancer is 99 percent curable if caught in its early stages, the ICR said.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	0	58	111	Progress in fighting lung cancer at specialist summit 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	1	195	400	Cancer specialists, gathered for an annual meeting, are reporting progress in the fight against lung cancer, the most common and deadliest form of cancer, but little progress in treating colorectal cancer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	2	410	635	Doctors and researchers at the 45th gathering of the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) -- the world's main cancer conference -- on Saturday learned of two studies showing progress in the battle against lung cancer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	3	645	786	The first study showed how the combination of two anti-cancer treatments following standard chemotherapy can slow the advance of lung cancer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	4	796	1002	Patients treated with a combination of Tarceva, sold by the Swiss drugmaker Roche, and Avastin, a drug by Roche's Genentech unit, saw their cancer growth slow more than a control group treated with Avastin. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	5	1012	1108	More than 750 patients were randomized to receive Avastin and a placebo, or Avastin and Tarceva. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	6	1109	1302	Those in the Tarceva group survived an average of 4.8 months before the cancer started growing again, compared to 3.7 months for the control group, said Vincent Miller, the study's main author. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	7	1312	1446	The numbers translated to a 29 percent reduced risk of disease progression for patients who took a combination of Tarceva and Avastin. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	8	1456	1700	"This is the first study to show that adding erlotinib (Tarceva) to maintenance therapy with bevacizumab (Avastin) delays disease progression in patients who have already received bevacizumab as part of their initial chemotherapy," said Miller. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	9	1710	1855	A second study with 663 patients with advance lung cancer were given the drug Alimta, from US pharmaceutical Eli Lilly, which blocks cell growth. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	10	1865	2029	Preliminary results showed that patients who took the drug lived 26 percent longer compared to a control group that took a placebo: 13.4 months against 10.6 months. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	11	2039	2136	As in the first study, all the patients had already received four standard chemotherapy sessions. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	12	2146	2308	"This study will change the overall standard of care," said Chandra Belani, the deputy director of the Penn State Cancer Institute, as she presented the research. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	13	2318	2567	"Maintenance therapy with Alimta (permetrexed) offers a new paradigm for patients who have advanced lung cancer, because it has a low toxicity and can be given on an ongoing basis over a prolonged period of time to extend patients' lives," she said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	14	2577	2743	However there were few advances to report in the fight against colorectal cancer, the fourth most common in the United States and the second deadliest type of cancer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	15	2753	3028	Research on 2,710 patients with Phase Three colorectal cancer taking the drug Avastine along with standard chemotherapy treatment showed no difference in the survival rate or the recurrence of the tumor after three and a half years when compared to those not taking the drug. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	16	3038	3285	Another study conducted in Italy among 747 patients with advanced colorectal cancer showed that the drug Eloxatine from the French firm Sanofi did not reduce the size of the tumor when combined with standard treatment used ahead of cancer surgery. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0341	17	3295	3449	On Sunday, several sessions at the ASCO event, scheduled to end on Tuesday, will focus on the result of clinical tests on female breast and uterus cancer.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	0	58	109	Climate change: 'Bali Road Map' looks for a compass 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	1	182	349	Gruelling efforts to craft a pact on climate change enter a crucial phase on Monday when the 192-nation UN forum takes its first look at a draft text for negotiations. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	2	359	568	The 12-day huddle in the German city of Bonn under the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) means that, after 18 months of swapping visions, the process will at last get down to the gritty stuff. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	3	578	817	Little more than six months are left before the "Bali Road Map", launched in Indonesia in 2006, reaches its supposed destination at a Copenhagen summit: an accord that will transform global warming from a monster into a manageable problem. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	4	827	955	On the table is a small mountain of paper whose notable feature is curly brackets, denoting discord among scores of submissions. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	5	965	1145	Despite the sprawling range of proposals, UNFCCC Executive Secretary Yvo de Boer said he hoped that the draft will be endorsed as a workable basis for talks over the coming months. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	6	1155	1235	"There will be a negotiating text on the table for the first time," he told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	7	1245	1383	"I hope it will be well received, that it will be seen as a balanced representation of the different ideas that countries have come with." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	8	1393	1480	The big goal is to slash emissions of greenhouse gases by 2050 compared to 1990 levels. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	9	1490	1530	But that's where consensus largely ends. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	10	1531	1569	Exactly how deep should be the cut be? 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	11	1570	1593	How can it be achieved? 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	12	1594	1629	And who should shoulder the burden? 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	13	1639	1836	In their proposals, many developing countries say rich countries, which bear historical responsibility for today's warming, should take the lead by cutting their emissions by 25-40 percent by 2020. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	14	1846	1913	China has led the charge, demanding a cut of "at least" 40 percent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	15	1923	2105	But only the European Union (EU), which has set its own reduction of 20 percent by 2020, deepened to 30 percent if other advanced economies play ball, is anywhere near such a figure. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	16	2115	2258	After eight long years of vilification, the United States is now being warmly embraced in the climate arena as Barack Obama bulldozes George W. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	17	2259	2275	Bush's policies. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	18	2285	2354	But Washington is also warning that the world cannot expect miracles. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	19	2364	2507	A bill put before Congress would cut US emissions by 17 percent by 2020 over 2005 levels using a cap-and-trade system of the kind Bush loathed. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	20	2517	2741	This approach would translate to a reduction of only four percent compared to the 1990 benchmark, but it would also ratchet up to 83 percent by 2050, the top US climate change negotiator, Todd Stern, said in Paris last week. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	21	2751	2904	"We are jumping as high as the political system will tolerate," said Stern, characterising China's demand of a 40 percent cut by 2020 as "not realistic". 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	22	2914	2980	Just as unresolved is what the emerging giant countries should do. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	23	2990	3123	The draft should at least "call for those wealthier, more capable countries to take actions," said Stern's deputy, Jonathan Pershing. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	24	3133	3263	China is now the world's No. 1 polluter, and Brazil and India have also leapt up the emission ranks as their economies have grown. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	25	3273	3456	Yet all refuse binding emissions targets of the kind that apply only to rich countries under the Kyoto Protocol, the UNFCCC treaty to be superseded from 2013 by the Copenhagen accord. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	26	3466	3672	Then there is how to muster finance to help poor countries adapt to the impacts of climate change, and how to transfer clean technology so that they avoid becoming the greenhouse-gas villains of the future. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	27	3682	3843	Keya Chatterjee, deputy director of the climate change programme with the World Wildlife Fund (WWF) said emerging countries were thirsting for the energy switch. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	28	3853	3959	"It's sort of a green arms race where everybody wants to have access to clean- energy industry," she said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	29	3960	4040	"That's a pretty huge change in the negotiations that will affect the dynamics." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	30	4050	4106	Even so, she said, developing countries were suspicious. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	31	4107	4219	"This lack of trust comes from a long tradition of industrialised countries not living up to their obligations." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	32	4229	4300	These are just a few of the many obstacles besetting the Bali Road Map. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	33	4310	4449	The complexity is such that many experts now predict Copenhagen will not be a complete treaty but, at best, a good deal on the main points. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0346	34	4459	4756	"I think that what we are looking at in Copenhagen is a deal that will lock in some specific emission reductions goals, will create commitments both for investment and adaptation and then... the details will have to be filled in later," said Angela Anderson of the US Climate Action Network (CAN).

AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	3	594	844	He said the plan takes into account sensitive regions where violence could erupt on election day between members of the current Western-backed ruling majority and supporters of the Hezbollah-led opposition alliance, which is backed by Iran and Syria.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	7	1282	1351	"And it's according to the risk factor that troops will be deployed."

AFP_ENG_20090531.0348	9	1535	1724	However, the situation is expected to be more tense in regions where the vote is set to be tight, including the southern coastal town of Sidon and in the eastern Bekaa valley town of Zahle.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0359	2	364	611	The party, which also wants to beef up Internet privacy, was founded in January 2006 and quickly attracted members angered by controversial laws adopted in the Scandinavian country that criminalised filesharing and authorised monitoring of emails. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0359	3	621	793	Its membership shot up after a Stockholm court on April 17 sentenced four Swedes to a year in jail for running one of the world's biggest filesharing sites, The Pirate Bay.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	1	178	286	The European Union parliament has long had the image of being a gravy-train but an EU election is no picnic. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	2	296	361	The voting system is as arcane as the 27-nation EU is widespread. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	3	362	496	The election for the 736 lawmakers takes four days and there will be weeks of bargaining afterwards to settle the assembly's top jobs. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	4	506	563	Voting starts on Thursday in Britain and the Netherlands. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	5	564	702	Ireland holds its election on the following day, the Czech Republic on June 5 and 6, and Slovakia Latvia, Malta and Cyprus vote on June 6. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	6	712	818	France, Germany, Italy, Spain and the other 15 countries in the EU all hold their elections on the Sunday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	7	819	900	The first reliable forecasts will come out about 2000 GMT on the night of June 7. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	8	910	960	Each country uses its own preferred voting system. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	9	970	1181	While any EU citizen can stand as a candidate or vote in any EU country where he or she is resident and registered on the electoral list, rules such as the minimum age for voting changes from country to country. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	10	1191	1235	There were 785 deputies in the old assembly. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	11	1236	1308	The Treaty of Nice ordered the cutback but this could be only temporary. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	12	1309	1401	If the Treaty of Lisbon is ever ratified by every member the number will go up again to 754. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	13	1411	1480	Each country's representation is roughly in line with its population. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	14	1481	1527	Malta, the smallest member, has five deputies. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	15	1528	1557	Germany, the biggest, has 99. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	16	1558	1663	The other main powers -- Britain, France and Italy -- have 72 each, while Poland and Spain elect 50 each. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0361	17	1673	1791	One of the big unknowns is how the extra 18 deputies will be shared out, if the Lisbon reform treaty comes into force.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0383	0	58	93	Indian author Kamala Das dead at 75 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0383	1	170	334	Writer and poet Kamala Das, known for her frank discussion of female sexuality in conservative India, died in hospital on Sunday, the Press Trust of India reported. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0383	2	335	346	She was 75. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0383	3	356	463	Das died in the western city of Pune after a long illness, PTI said, without specifying the cause of death. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0383	4	473	621	Das was born into a family of writers and wrote poems and short stories in English and Malayalam, the language of her southern home state of Kerala. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0383	5	631	843	She was one of the first Indian writers to explore sexual themes in her work, and her 1976 autobiography, My Story, was a candid recollection of her own sexual coming of age that was translated into 15 languages. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0383	6	853	999	Das converted to Islam in 1999 and took the name Kamala Surayya, but later appeared to regret it, saying "God has no connection with any religion. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0383	7	1000	1040	There is no respect for women anywhere." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0383	8	1050	1149	She also dabbled in politics, launching the Lok Seva Party but failing to win a seat in parliament. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0383	9	1159	1187	Das is survived by two sons.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	0	58	112	GM bondholders approve debt restructuring deal: report 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	1	190	372	Ailing General Motors moved closer Sunday to its expected bankruptcy filing as company bondholders approved a  government-sponsored debt for equity deal, The New York Times reported. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	2	382	551	The bondholders had until 5:00 pm (2100 GMT) Saturday to indicate whether they supported the group's new offer ahead of the once mighty corporation's looming bankruptcy. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	3	561	688	The government's rescue plan for GM could put as much as 72.5 percent of the country's biggest automaker under state ownership. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	4	698	909	Citing "people briefed on the matter," the newspaper said the bondholders with slightly more than 50 percent of GM’s 27.2 billion dollars in bond debt agreed to support the plan by the government-set deadline. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	5	919	1041	Among the backers was a committee of large investors holding about 20 percent of GM’s outstanding bonds, The Times said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	6	1051	1112	No official announcement of the vote tally has yet been made. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	7	1122	1234	Under the plan, the bondholders would obtain the rights to buy an extra 15 percent of GM's stock at a low price. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	8	1235	1357	They would also control 25 percent of the "new GM," after having supported the new company's creation in bankruptcy court. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	9	1367	1534	Recalcitrant bondholders who opt for confrontation rather than cooperation "will get nothing or very little," an Obama administration official told reporters Thursday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	10	1544	1804	Government-backed restructuring in bankruptcy court for GM, once the world's largest automaker, appeared all but certain ahead of a Monday deadline imposed by the Obama administration on the company to submit a viable restructuring plan or file for bankruptcy. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0387	11	1814	1853	It could take place as early as Sunday.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	2	380	565	Foreign Minister Rohitha Bogollagama told a high-level security forum in Singapore that the global organisation of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) remained "largely intact." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	3	575	718	"Many of the operatives have clearly cultivated powerful, political lobbies in certain capitals with a view to resurrecting the LTTE," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	4	728	1018	"It is important for the international community to take all measures to assist the government of Sri Lanka to track down the global network of the LTTE," he told an annual forum of defence and military officials organised by the London- based International Institute for Strategic Studies. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	5	1028	1283	Sri Lanka's military claimed complete victory over the separatist Tamil Tigers after wiping out the guerrillas' leadership nearly two weeks ago, but has been dogged by accusations that thousands of civilians were killed in the final weeks of the campaign. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	6	1293	1390	The LTTE launched a campaign in 1972 to create a Tamil homeland in the Sinhalese-majority island. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	7	1391	1437	Much of its funding came from Tamils overseas. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	8	1447	1609	Bogollagama dismissed allegations that heavy weapons were used by the military in civilian areas as part of the "propaganda of genocide against the Tamil people." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	9	1619	1802	"This was both fictional and well-fabricated, with ulterior and sinister motives in order to discredit the armed forces as well as to embarrass the government of Sri Lanka," he added. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	10	1812	2115	"Sri Lanka will no doubt enter the annals of history as a classic textbook example of a nation that successfully prevailed over the scourge of terrorism, whilst tenaciously upholding the cherished values of democracy and human rights that have been deeply engraved in the psyche of our people," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0388	11	2125	2242	"The government is firmly committed to reaching a political settlement acceptable to all," the foreign minister said.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0389	1	188	355	Haitian-born American Andre Berto retained his World Boxing Council welterweight title Saturday with a lopsided unanimous 12-round decision over Colombian Juan Urango. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0389	2	365	458	Two judges scored the bout 118-110 for the Florida-based Berto, while a third saw it 117-111. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0389	3	468	552	Berto remained unbeaten in 25 professional fights, with 19 wins inside the distance. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0389	4	562	682	Urango was frustrated by the nimble Berto, who kept his distance and scored to the head with the jab and with his right. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0389	5	692	781	Urango' best round was the fourth, when he landed a series of lefts to the head and body. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0389	6	791	969	But Berto largely avoided Urango's pressure, givig him little opportunity to get inside in the middle rounds while connecting himself with shots to Urango's head with both hands. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0389	7	979	1082	After a lackluster ninth round drew jeers from the crowd, Berto stepped it up in the last three rounds. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0389	8	1092	1268	Urango, who fell to 21-2-1 with 16 wins inside the distance, will now return to the super lightweight ranks, where he is still the International Boxing Federation title holder.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	0	58	93	Taliban take war to Pakistan cities 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	1	170	362	Taliban rebels in Pakistan are taking their war to the cities, honing terror tactics to maximise civilian carnage after suffering heavy losses in a blistering military offensive, analysts say. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	2	372	589	Pakistan has been rocked by 14 bomb blasts that have killed more than 80 people in urban areas since it launched a determined air and ground assault against the Taliban in pockets of the northwest at the end of April. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	3	599	810	The military said on Saturday that troops had regained control of the main town of Mingora in Swat valley from the Taliban, in what is being touted as a significant milestone in the month-long ongoing offensive. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	4	820	1046	But the rebels, who Washington fears threaten Pakistan's very existence, are striking back in cities like the regional capital Peshawar, about 200 kilometres (125 miles) from Mingora and previously shielded from major attacks. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	5	1056	1221	"They are taking this war to the cities, hoping to build up enough pressure on the government to halt the military activity," security analyst Hasan Askari told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	6	1231	1383	"The Taliban challenge now threatens routine life and commercial activity in cities... allied extremist groups are facilitating their agenda," he added. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	7	1393	1560	Attackers are becoming increasingly sophisticated, analysts say, executing commando-style assaults armed with suicide vests, vehicle bombs, guns, grenades and rockets. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	8	1570	1761	Over the last two weeks in Peshawar, bombs have exploded outside a cinema, near crowded electronics shops, at a police checkpoint and even alongside a bus full of children with special needs. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	9	1771	1968	And in Lahore, Pakistan's entertainment capital, a bomb, gun and grenade assault killed 24 people and partially damaged the provincial headquarters of the country's premier spy agency on Wednesday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	10	1978	2124	It was the third spectacular assault in and around the eastern city -- hundreds of miles from the offensive in the northwest -- in as many months. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	11	2134	2309	The Tehreek-e-Taliban (TTP) militant group claimed responsibility, telling people in a statement they should get out of the cities because there will be more violence to come. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	12	2319	2543	Newspaper columnist Shafqat Mehmood said the Taliban, who want to enforce sharia law, are becoming more and more desperate in the face of the military onslaught in the northwest, which the army says has claimed 1,200 rebels. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	13	2553	2634	"Militants are under pressure and will employ any tactic to cause maximum damage. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	14	2635	2690	Urban terrorism is one of those tactics," said Mehmood. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	15	2700	2834	While the government could do more to protect key targets, he said, underfunded and overstretched security forces can only do so much. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	16	2844	2902	"It is difficult to patrol markets and streets," he added. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	17	2912	3036	"Our province is facing a war-like situation," the police chief of North West Frontier Province, Malik Naved Khan, told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	18	3046	3068	"We have 9,000 police. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	19	3069	3179	In a big city like Peshawar, this is not enough to deal with situations like the one we're facing," said Khan. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	20	3189	3392	Northwest expert Rahimullah Yusufzai said the Taliban were increasingly focused on civilian targets as widespread public opinion turns -- for the first time -- in favour of Pakistan's military operation. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	21	3402	3603	The offensive already has the firm backing of Washington, which says Al-Qaeda and Taliban have carved out safe havens in the northwestern areas bordering Afghanistan to plot terror attacks on the West. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	22	3613	3731	"The Taliban have jacked up attacks targeting civilians as they have failed to target security forces," Yusufzai said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	23	3741	3907	Echoing Hasan Askari, he added the Taliban will likely have willing allies from a catalogue of banned radical groups that traditionally have battled India in Kashmir. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	24	3917	4099	These include Lashkar-i-Jhangvi, Yusufzai said, an extremist element linked to Al-Qaeda, and Lashkar-e-Taiba, accused of carrying out the Mumbai attacks last year that left 166 dead. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	25	4109	4207	"These extremist outfits and TTP (Tehreek-e-Taliban) have a relationship that runs in their blood. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	26	4208	4263	They are natural allies who lived and fought together." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	27	4273	4452	Alarmingly, the government in Islamabad had no particular strategy to prevent attacks on cities, Yusufzai said, warning he did not see an end to the urban bloodshed any time soon. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0391	28	4462	4690	"I don't think the situation can be brought under control quickly because it has roots in (the tribal areas of) Waziristan and Bajaur, and what is happening in those two regions is linked to the Taliban in Afghanistan," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0392	0	58	108	Aung San Suu Kyi 'covered up' truth: Myanmar junta 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0392	1	185	380	Opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi "covered up" the truth by failing to report an American man in her home, a senior Myanmar official said Sunday, warning foreigners not to interfere in the case. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0392	2	390	642	"It is no doubt that Daw Aung San Suu Kyi has committed a cover-up of the truth by her failure to report an illegal immigrant to the authorities concerned," Major General Aye Myint, Myanmar's deputy defence minister, told a security forum in Singapore. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0392	3	652	745	"Thus there was no option but to open legal proceedings in accordance with the law," he said.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0392	10	1712	1859	Ann Taylor, Britain's minister for international defence and security, said at the meeting earlier Sunday that Aung San Suu Kyi should be released. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0392	11	1869	2066	"The continued imprisonment of Aung San Suu Kyi by the Burmese regime is a reminder that we cannot take for granted the institution of democracy," she said, referring to Myanmar by its former name. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0392	12	2076	2212	"The people of Burma have suffered for nearly half a century of conflict and isolation, but Aung San Suu Kyi is not alone," Taylor said.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0394	3	599	810	The military said on Saturday that troops had regained control of the main town of Mingora in Swat valley from the Taliban, in what is being touted as a significant milestone in the month-long ongoing offensive. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0394	4	820	1046	But the rebels, who Washington fears threaten Pakistan's very existence, are striking back in cities like the regional capital Peshawar, about 200 kilometres (125 miles) from Mingora and previously shielded from major attacks. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0394	5	1056	1221	"They are taking this war to the cities, hoping to build up enough pressure on the government to halt the military activity," security analyst Hasan Askari told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0394	6	1231	1383	"The Taliban challenge now threatens routine life and commercial activity in cities... allied extremist groups are facilitating their agenda," he added. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0394	7	1393	1560	Attackers are becoming increasingly sophisticated, analysts say, executing commando-style assaults armed with suicide vests, vehicle bombs, guns, grenades and rockets. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0394	8	1570	1761	Over the last two weeks in Peshawar, bombs have exploded outside a cinema, near crowded electronics shops, at a police checkpoint and even alongside a bus full of children with special needs.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0394	10	1978	2124	It was the third spectacular assault in and around the eastern city -- hundreds of miles from the offensive in the northwest -- in as many months. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0394	11	2134	2309	The Tehreek-e-Taliban (TTP) militant group claimed responsibility, telling people in a statement they should get out of the cities because there will be more violence to come.
