AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	0	58	109	Blogging guru chips away at Great Firewall of China 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	1	186	288	How would you react if one million of your customers were suddenly stopped from coming into your shop? 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	2	289	318	Matt Mullenweg just shrugged. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	3	328	474	The 25-year-old American is the founder of Wordpress, software that allows computer users worldwide to easily create their own websites, or blogs. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	4	484	742	The simplicity of Wordpress has made it one of the world's top blogging platforms six years after it was set up, its adherents ranging from knitting fanatics (jessinohio.wordpress.com) to CNN's resident doctor Sanjay Gupta (pagingdrgupta.blogs.cnn.com/site). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	5	752	856	But in 2006, as the site was growing from strength to strength, Chinese authorities suddenly blocked it. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	6	866	998	Overnight, one million Chinese visitors to the various blogs disappeared, accounting for about a quarter of all traffic to the site. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	7	1008	1201	"I wish there was a better story, but really it just went away one day and we didn't know what to do about it," Mullenweg told AFP, during a visit to Hong Kong to speak to some of his bloggers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	8	1211	1410	After some discussions, Mullenweg realised the site would be allowed back online if he agreed to block certain words or topics and give up information to the Chinese communist government about users. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	9	1420	1479	"I started thinking about the DNA of the company," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	10	1480	1577	"That sort of company is not one I would wake up every day and feel passionate about working in." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	11	1587	1735	The site remains blocked, although Mullenweg, unable to suppress a giggle, points out that the official Chinese line insists it is freely available. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	12	1745	2008	His decision not to pander to China contrasts sharply with other companies that have agreed to the country's extensive Internet controls -- often dubbed the Great Firewall of China -- in the hope of gaining access to what is now the world's biggest online market. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	13	2018	2024	Yahoo! 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	14	2025	2179	faced fierce criticism when it helped Chinese authorities identify a journalist who had passed on a sensitive Communist Party message to foreign websites. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	15	2180	2237	The journalist, Shi Tao, was subsequently jailed in 2005. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	16	2247	2462	"I imagine that weighs very heavily on both the leadership of that company and also the morale of an entire organisation," said Mullenweg, who is based in San Francisco and has done several recent deals with Yahoo!. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	17	2472	2659	Despite the ban, Chinese bloggers still use Wordpress technology in huge numbers, downloading its free access software and pasting their blogs through another server to avoid the censors. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	18	2669	2876	That's just the kind of technology-inspired rebellion that appeals to Mullenweg, who has also refused to submit to similar government demands in Turkey, and whose instinct is to make things freely-available. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	19	2886	3015	He is considering putting all the firm's expenses online, so everyone at Automattic, Wordpress's parent company, can access them. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	20	3016	3154	And his camera, which goes everywhere with him, carries a global positioning system, so he records the exact location of all his pictures. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	21	3164	3315	This openness is reflected in Wordpress's approach -- the blogging software is open source, so it can be downloaded and tinkered with as users see fit. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	22	3325	3476	As a result of its accessibility and it simplicity, it now has more than 15 million bloggers using its technology, according to statistics on the site. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	23	3486	3657	While setting up a blog is free, the site makes money by advertising or charging for extras, such as enhanced statistics packages or better promotion of a particular blog. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	24	3667	3870	Mullenweg has become the darling of the Internet world, regularly featuring on lists of the "most powerful people in cyberspace" and accepting invitations to talk about how the web is changing the world. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	25	3880	4172	The company, which still has fewer than 100 employees, remains privately held and so does not have to reveal earnings, and though reports have said Mullenweg turned down an offer of 200 million dollars in 2007 for a stake in the firm, money one of the few subjects he is reluctant to discuss. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	26	4182	4344	"We are doing well, capital is not a limiting factor for us," said Mullenweg, dressed in battered trainers and jeans after addressing a group of business leaders. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	27	4354	4489	"I like that we always get the question how do you make money, because it means that we are not crassly over-commercialising," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	28	4499	4631	His passion for simplicity was learned as teenage volunteer at the Houston Area League of PC Users, in the US city where he grew up. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	29	4632	4704	His job was fixing computers every Saturday for mainly elderly PC users. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	30	4714	4837	"You saw all the cliches -- CD-ROMS being used as a cup holder, but they were just trying to connect with (the technology). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	31	4838	4865	It was inspiring," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	32	4875	4964	"You really develop an appreciation (for simplicity) and developing software is the same. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0401	33	4974	5162	"People don't want to use Wordpress (for its own sake), they want to talk to their audience, share photos of their family and (Wordpress) is either a way for them to do that or it is not."

AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	1	208	460	The ancient mystery shrouding Lalibela, Ethiopia's revered medieval rock-hewn churches, could be lifted by a group of French researchers given the go-ahead for the first comprehensive study of this world heritage site legend says was "built by angels". 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	2	470	651	The team will have full access to the network of 10 Orthodox chapels chiseled out of volcanic rock -- some standing 15 metres (42 feet) high -- in the mountainous heart of Ethiopia. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	3	661	840	Local lore holds they were built in less than 25 years by their namesake, the 13th-century King Lalibela, with the help of angels after God ordered him to erect a "New Jerusalem". 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	4	850	948	The monolithic structures are located 500 kilometres (300 miles) north of the capital Addis Ababa. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	5	949	1111	Long a holy pilgrimage site in a land proud of its Christian Orthodox heritage, they are also a travel draw in a poverty-stricken country hoping to boost tourism. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	6	1121	1309	The multidisciplinary team of historians, archaeologists, topographers and a specialist in liturgy will spend several weeks probing the subterranean complex to try to identify its origins. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	7	1319	1435	Historian Marie Laure Derat, with the French Centre for Ethiopian Studies (CFEE), said "there are several theories". 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	8	1436	1591	In one, "an Egyptian patriarch was believed to be the source of these structures, another says the 13th-century King Lalibela built the site from scratch." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	9	1601	1705	"During the day the king would work with Ethiopian artisans and at night he would 'be helped by angels'. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	10	1706	1848	Some even cite a key role by the Knights Templar," she said, referring to one of the key Western Christian military orders of the Middle Ages. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	11	1858	2004	Though earlier studies have been carried out, they were generally by lone researchers with restricted access who studied mainly church interiors . 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	12	2014	2245	Derat said the heretofore reluctant Orthodox church gave the French team carte blanche to probe "the entire site, not just the churches, to understand how the periods overlap and to read history in this open book that is Lalibela". 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	13	2255	2376	Funded by the French government and Ethiopian Airlines, the team is already certain the chapels were not built in one go. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	14	2386	2574	Research chief Francois Xavier Fauvelle said three distinct periods have been identified in the maze of deep tunnels, passageways and chapels, some of which resemble ancient Greek temples. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	15	2584	2667	"There was originally a basalt dome under which we found evidence of cave dwellers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	16	2668	2842	Then there was the construction of a fortress with trenches, a perimetre wall and underground tunnels," he said pointing to rocks he said where once part of the defence wall. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	17	2852	3090	"The third period was established thanks to an enormous mound of earth about 20 metres high that came from the excavation of the church of Gabriel Ruphael," he said, referring to the chapel some believe was once King Lalibela's residence. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	18	3100	3269	"The Ruphael Gabriel church was probably part of the fortress and was turned into a church: the facade was extended, windows opened and a chapel dug out," said Fauvelle. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	19	3279	3472	UNESCO added Lalibela to its world heritage list in 1978, a boon for tourism efforts in this country of 85 million where poverty is rampant and agriculture accounts for nearly half the economy. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	20	3473	3527	Visitors can already join organized tours of the site. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	21	3537	3689	But the bid to shed light on its origins has not shaken the Orthodox clergy and faithful here, who contend that Lalibela arose with divine intervention. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	22	3699	3871	"It is God through his angels who made these churches," said Alebachew Reta, spokesman for the Lalibela clergy who insisted "the 10 churches were created in just 24 years." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	23	3881	3962	"You can observe that even one would be difficult to build in that space of time. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	24	3963	4002	So for us it is God's work," said Reta. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0403	25	4003	4080	"For the one who created mankind, building these churches was not difficult." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	0	58	118	Jewish settlers say they remain in West Bank on God's orders 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	1	208	339	The world outcry over Israeli settlements in the West Bank is absurd since God gave this land to the Jews, says Rabbi Yaakov Savir. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	2	340	393	The Arabs, he says, should make their home elsewhere. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	3	403	643	"This territory is Jewish territory," says Savir, a settler who runs a religious school in the Havat Gilad outpost which consists of little more than a few tin huts and weather-worn trailers, some horses and chickens and several car wrecks. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	4	653	866	"This is our home," he says, making a sweeping gesture towards the Jewish settlements that dominate nearby hilltops to show he means the entire West Bank, which Israel captured from Jordan in the 1967 Six-Day-War. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	5	876	1031	Havat Gilad, which 20 families call home, is a wildcat outpost, meaning that unlike full-scale settlements, it is not authorised by the Israeli government. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	6	1041	1181	The international community considers all settlements illegal, and the issue is one of the thorniest in peace efforts with the Palestinians. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	7	1191	1310	With US pressure mounting, Israel could soon make good on its years-old pledge to tear down a couple of dozen outposts. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	8	1320	1373	In Havat Gilad's case, it wouldn't be the first time. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	9	1383	1624	Built by Moshe Zar, a former member of a Jewish underground movement that planted bombs in the cars of Arab mayors, the outpost was torn down by the Israeli authorities barely hours after a group of teenagers pitched the first tents in 2002. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	10	1625	1657	Rebuilding started the next day. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	11	1667	1792	Savir is outraged the government of right-wing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu would even consider bulldozing Jewish homes. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	12	1802	2073	"Jewish people live here by Biblical right," he claims, standing in the trailer that houses the religious school, surrounded by students who sport the look favoured by ideologically motivated religious settlers -- long locks, knitted skullcap, loose clothing and sandals. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	13	2083	2202	Savir insists he has nothing against Arabs -- he won't speak of Palestinians other than to say there is no such people. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	14	2212	2276	"If Arabs want to stay, we won't kill them, we won't expel them. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	15	2286	2374	"They are the ones who want to kill us, who don't want us to live in our home," he says. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	16	2384	2437	"Arabs," he adds "should find another place to live." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	17	2447	2601	The vast majority of the 280,000 Jews who live in the 120 West Bank settlements which Israel considers legal, have moved to the area for economic reasons. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	18	2602	2740	But the hardliners who share Savir's views that Jewish people have a God-given right to the land are extremely vocal and at times violent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	19	2750	2881	Rabbi Savir is convinced the residents of Havat Gilad, like others in similar outposts, "will certainly fight for every millimeter. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	20	2882	2910	No one will leave his home." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	21	2920	3052	Israel agreed in 2003 to freeze all settlement activity and raze wildcat outposts but has not followed through on those commitments. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	22	3062	3293	Outposts, typically located a few hundred metres (yards) from government- authorised settlements, include anything from a few shacks to communities of several dozen semi-permanent homes connected to the electricity and water grids. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	23	3303	3481	Many of the 100 or so outposts were built on West Bank hills by militant teenagers, known as "hilltop youths," with the aim of planting the seeds of new full-fledged settlements. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	24	3491	3692	A 2005 government-commissioned report said that in some cases officials authorised seizure of private Palestinian land to create outposts, and facilitated their connection to the water and power mains. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	25	3702	3870	Palestinians see the outposts as part of a land grab and a scheme to further consolidate Israel's control over the West Bank, which is home to 2.4 million Palestinians. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	26	3880	4120	Faced with mounting pressure from within his right-wing coalition on the one hand and the United States on the other, Netanyahu has vowed to continue building in existing settlement blocs while indicating he will dismantle wildcat outposts. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	27	4130	4171	But he has failed to placate either side. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	28	4181	4344	The premier has faced fierce criticism from the right for his willingness to tear down Jewish homes, and some blunt talk from Washington over settlement expansion. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	29	4354	4477	US President Barack Obama told Netanyahu during May 18 White House talks he wants a complete freeze of settlement activity. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	30	4487	4619	"Not some settlements, not outposts, not natural growth exceptions," Secretary of State Hillary Clinton said, explaining the demand. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	31	4629	4811	Israeli police did tear down Maoz Esther, north of the West Bank political capital of Ramallah, on May 21, but the move was dismissed by Israeli media as a meaningless token gesture. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	32	4812	4871	The outpost consisted of just seven tin and plywood shacks. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	33	4881	5024	One week after the demolition, one house had already been rebuilt and another was being constructed without any hindrance from the authorities. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	34	5034	5256	"We must settle here, God has ordered us to live on this land," says Daniel Landesberg, 20, as he and a group of teenagers spread out cement being poured out of a large concrete mixer truck to form the base of a new house. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	35	5266	5350	Landesberg is a firm believer in the "doubling" tactic adopted by hardline settlers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	36	5360	5425	"They tore down seven homes, we will build 14," he says, smiling. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	37	5435	5459	And if the 14 are razed? 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0404	38	5460	5490	"We'll build twice that many."

AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	0	58	88	Struggling GM thrives in China 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	1	164	278	GM's overall future may look grim, but half a world away from Detroit in Shanghai, business has never been better. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	2	288	405	The US auto giant is beating sales records in China and may soon be exporting Chinese-made cars to the United States. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	3	415	461	"I don't think it makes much difference to us. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	4	462	624	Obviously we'd prefer to have this restructuring done outside the courts," Kevin Wale, GM China's president and managing director, told AFP in a recent interview. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	5	634	740	"We operate as independent joint ventures here in China so we would continue pretty much as we are today." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	6	750	969	While GM pares back at home, it may add a plant in China to meet its goal of doubling annual sales to two million within five years with products developed for "the most important growth market in the world", Wale said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	7	979	1179	That extra capacity could also help produce GM cars which for the first time would be exported from China to the United States, under a proposal the automaker has reportedly submitted to US lawmakers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	8	1189	1406	GM has proposed shipping 17,335 Chinese-made cars to the US in 2011 and increasing that to 51,546 by 2014 -- representing 1.6 percent of its forecast 3.1 million cars five years from now, the Automotive News reported. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	9	1416	1656	China led the world in auto sales in April, and GM China's joint ventures led the pack, with sales rising 29.9 percent on year to 151,084 vehicles, driven by demand for Buicks and small Wuling "bread vans" that cost less than 5,000 dollars. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	10	1666	1818	"It's definitely one of the market leaders here -- in drastic contrast to their performance in the US," said Shen Jun, an auto analyst at Roland Berger. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	11	1828	1938	GM's first Shanghai sales office opened in 1929, boasting: "Buick owners are mostly the leading men in China." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	12	1948	2046	Pu Yi, the last emperor, revolutionary leader Sun Yat-sen and premier Zhou Enlai all owned Buicks. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	13	2056	2175	But that history is barely known, allowing GM to recast Buick as a car for China's young and fast-growing middle class. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	14	2185	2378	"Volkswagen has good prices and good quality, but their cars look very average, not unique," said Li Pengxiang, a 29-year-old telecoms project manager, referring to China's number two carmaker. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	15	2388	2445	"These new (GM) models look fresh and suit young people." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	16	2455	2681	GM has earned a reputation for savvy marketing with moves like enlisting "Prison Break" star Wentworth Miller -- a top celebrity in China despite the show never airing here legally -- to star in its latest campaign, Shen said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	17	2691	2913	"They think they are doing much better than the parent company in the US," he said, saying GM's success in China boils down to smart decisions, good timing and luck that has put it far ahead of US rivals Ford and Chrysler. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	18	2923	3152	GM teamed with China's largest automaker Shanghai Automotive Industry Group or SAIC, in 1997 -- foreign carmakers here need a local joint venture partner -- after SAIC rejected Toyota and before Ford could sign a deal, Shen said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	19	3162	3341	Tension among joint venture partners is common, but GM and SAIC are known to have unrivalled chemistry, according to Zhu Junyi, an auto analyst at the Shanghai Information Centre. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	20	3351	3459	GM spends heavily on research and development while delegating key responsibilities to its partner, he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	21	3469	3563	"German and Japanese investors are more reluctant to give away any leadership role," Zhu said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	22	3564	3609	"GM has done a better job with localisation." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	23	3619	3783	GM's growing sales are impressive but competitors are growing faster -- Hyundai shot up 74 percent on year last month while Nissan sales grew 55 percent, Shen said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	24	3793	3928	Even as the Chinese market's growth slows -- to eight percent in 2008 after years of double digit growth -- more players are piling in. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0406	25	3938	4058	"The Japanese automakers are steamrolling China's auto market," said Eric Xu, head of Timer-Auto Consulting in Shanghai. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	0	58	110	GM's collapse will mark end of a blue collar dynasty 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	1	195	389	The expected collapse of General Motors will mark the death of a blue collar dynasty which bestowed upon generations of Americans the security of a job for life and a ticket to the middle class. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	2	399	501	"GM represented the good life," said Gary Chaison, a professor of labor relations at Clark University. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	3	511	640	"There was a social contract: you worked hard and the company would reward you with job security and good pay," Chaison told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	4	641	698	"And this was something you could pass on (to your kids.) 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	5	699	722	It was an inheritance." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	6	732	889	In towns and cities scattered across the midwest, GM's sprawling plants and the businesses which cropped up to service them brought prosperity and stability. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	7	899	1079	The United Auto Workers union won wages high enough to allow factory workers to own a home, a cottage, a boat, to take summer vacations in cars they bought with employee discounts. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	8	1089	1125	Their health insurance was paid for. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	9	1126	1179	Pensions would offer guaranteed income in retirement. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	10	1180	1233	They worked for the biggest corporation in the world. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	11	1243	1365	That dream began to slip away in the 1980s, when GM began shutting down plants and shipping production to Mexico and Asia. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	12	1375	1508	Once bustling company towns like Flint, Michigan -- memorialized in Michael Moore's documentary "Roger &amp; Me" -- emptied and died. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	13	1509	1603	Abandoned houses and darkened storefronts transformed the once rich region into the Rust Belt. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	14	1613	1677	GM employed 440,000 hourly workers in the United States in 1981. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	15	1687	1724	By 2000, that had dropped to 133,000. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	16	1725	1773	In the next eight years it would fall to 62,000. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	17	1783	1929	The latest restructuring plan calls for the unionized workforce to shrink to 38,000 by 2011: less than a tenth of what it was two decades earlier. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	18	1939	2110	But even through the downsizing and plant closures of the 1980s and 1990s, the workers who remained at General Motors were able to hang onto their high wages and benefits. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	19	2120	2325	That ended in the latest round of restructuring, which began in 2005 and ended with the union agreeing to slash benefits, cut wages in half for new workers, and even give up the right to strike until 2015. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	20	2335	2433	"It could have been worse," said Doug Bowman, the president of UAW Local 594 in Pontiac, Michigan. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	21	2443	2575	Bowman has worked for GM for 30 years and has watched employment at his complex shrink from 14,000 in the late 1970s to 1,000 today. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	22	2585	2690	He's anxiously awaiting news about whether his truck plant will be among 14 GM plants slated for closure. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	23	2691	2779	But he's resigned himself to the massive concessions the union has made in recent years. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	24	2789	2868	"The one thing I regret is that we couldn't protect the retirees," he told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	25	2878	2948	"We have no choice," said Jim Hall, another UAW official from Pontiac. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	26	2958	3024	"We have to vote for the concessions to help the company survive." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	27	3034	3064	But Hall hasn't given up hope. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	28	3065	3236	If GM manages to emerge from bankruptcy protection, which it is expected to seek in the coming days, Hall thinks some of jobs, and some of those benefits, might come back. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	29	3246	3463	GM, which only months ago lost the title of the world's biggest automaker to Toyota after holding it for 77 years, had made huge steps in recent years to revitalize its products and slash its bloated structural costs. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	30	3473	3642	But the restructuring cost billions and the debt-laden automaker was unable to survive the collapse of auto sales last fall amid a credit crunch and deepening recession. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	31	3652	3870	GM racked up nearly 88 billion dollars in losses from 2005 through the first quarter of 2009, and has only managed to keep its operations afloat in recent months with 19.4 billion dollars in loans from the US Treasury. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	32	3880	4052	The hope is that, like Chrysler, GM will emerge from bankruptcy in a matter of weeks as a leaner, meaner company able to get back to the business of making cars and trucks. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	33	4062	4220	But while the union is likely to hold a large stake in the new General Motors, its power to shape the American social landscape through sheer numbers is gone. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	34	4230	4341	"Certainly an era has ended," said Harley Shaiken, a labor expert from the University of California - Berkeley. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0407	35	4351	4379	"We're in uncharted waters." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	0	58	113	Once the world's biggest corporation, GM faces collapse 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	1	198	344	Once the biggest corporation in the world, steady growth overseas was unable to rescue General Motors from spiralling losses in the United States. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	2	354	480	Founded in 1908, GM sold more vehicles than any other automaker from 1931 until 2008, when it was overtaken by Japan's Toyota. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	3	490	637	The largest of the Detroit Three automakers, GM has seen its US market share fall from a peak of 54 percent in the 1954 to just 22 percent in 2008. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	4	647	800	It nonetheless sold a whopping 8.35 million vehicles in 2008 despite a collapse in global auto sales amid a credit crunch and widening economic downturn. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	5	810	945	GM last made a profit in 2004, earning 2.8 billion dollars, and has been operating under ever-deepening restructuring plans ever since. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	6	946	1024	It lost nearly 88 billion dollars from 2005 through the first quarter of 2009. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	7	1034	1196	Global employment levels reached more than 850,000 in 1978, of which more than 600,000 were in the United States, making GM the nation's largest private employer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	8	1206	1319	By 2005 it had already shrunk to 335,000 people and further cuts this year will bring it below 200,000 worldwide. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	9	1329	1386	GM's unionized workforce has taken the most dramatic hit. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	10	1387	1451	GM employed 440,000 hourly workers in the United States in 1981. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	11	1461	1544	By 2000, that had dropped to 133,000 and the automaker ended 2008 with just 62,000. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	12	1554	1700	The latest restructuring plan calls for the unionized workforce to shrink to 38,000 by 2011: less than a tenth of what it was two decades earlier. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	13	1710	1950	Once studied in business schools for the success of its brands, which operated as separate divisions aimed to satisfy different segments of the market, GM is shedding most of its marks -- including Sweden's Saab, Hummer, Pontiac and Saturn. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	14	1951	2009	It will concentrate on Cadillac, Buick, Chevrolet and GMC. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0408	15	2019	2139	The latest restructuring plan will shrink GM's US dealer network by 40 percent and will cut its US plants from 47 to 31. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	0	58	99	Troubled road which led to GM's breakdown 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	1	184	334	Here are the principal events marking GM's troubled path over the past 18 months, with the once mighty automaker expected to file for bankruptcy soon. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	2	344	356	JANUARY 2008 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	3	366	470	-- Toyota comes close to overtaking GM as the world's biggest automaker, a title GM has held since 1931. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0409	4	471	559	GM sells 9.369 million vehicles in 2007 while the Japanese automaker sold 9.366 million.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	0	58	110	Collapse of once mighty GM was decades in the making 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	1	185	375	The downfall of General Motors comes after decades of mistakes and missteps chipped away at the reputation and market share of the once mighty automaker and buried the Detroit giant in debt. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	2	385	562	"It'll have a huge impact in the United States because it's more than just a corporation -- it's an icon," said Gary Chaison, a professor of labor relations at Clark University. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	3	572	647	"It represented manufacturing supremacy and good jobs for American workers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	4	648	661	That's gone." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	5	671	888	GM, which only months ago lost the title of the world's biggest automaker to Toyota after holding it for 77 years, had made huge steps in recent years to revitalize its products and slash its bloated structural costs. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	6	898	1072	But the restructuring cost billions and the debt-laden automaker has fought hard to survive the collapse of auto sales last fall amid a credit crunch and deepening recession. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	7	1082	1175	GM racked up nearly 88 billion dollars in losses from 2005 through the first quarter of 2009. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	8	1185	1368	It managed to keep its operations afloat in recent months with 19.4 billion dollars in loans from the US Treasury but is now expected to seek bankruptcy protection in the coming days. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	9	1378	1490	"GM's problems go back at least three decades," said Terrence Guay, a professor at Penn State's business school. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	10	1500	1640	"The company became complacent in terms of products and customers, assuming that American car-buyers would choose GM vehicles," he told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	11	1650	1788	"They didn't take the Japanese threat seriously, and consequently steadily lost market share to Toyota, Honda, Nissan, and other imports." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	12	1798	1983	GM was a giant in its chrome-detailed heyday, employing more than 600,000 people worldwide and 464,000 in the United States back in 1962 when it sold more than half the cars in America. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	13	1993	2195	Founded in 1908, GM grew to be the largest private US employer, the world's biggest company, had revenues higher than the gross domestic product of most nations, and currently operates in 140 countries. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	14	2205	2415	After transforming its plants to make planes, tanks and munitions during World War II, GM expanded far beyond cars in the decades to follow, building everything from trains and rockets to home air conditioners. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	15	2425	2592	GM also helped expand the American middle class with the standard-setting high wages and solid benefit packages won by hundreds of thousands of unionized auto workers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	16	2602	2677	The phrase "what's good for GM is good for the country" became commonplace. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	17	2687	2816	"Between 1921 and 1980 they never lost money," said Sean McAlinden, chief economist at Michigan's Center for Automotive Research. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	18	2826	2899	"The target was a 20 percent return on capital every year no matter what. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	19	2900	2917	And they did it." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	20	2927	3109	But GM and its Detroit neighbors, Ford and Chrysler, let their quality slip and fumbled the shift to smaller, more fuel efficient vehicles in the wake of the oil crises of the 1970s. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	21	3119	3227	"The baby boom generation has never forgiven them for the defects of the 1970s and 80s," McAlinden told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	22	3237	3296	"They will go to their graves without buying a GM vehicle." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	23	3306	3464	Japanese automakers Toyota and Honda steadily gained market share first with the low cost of their vehicles and then with their reputation for higher quality. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	24	3474	3562	Plant closures became a part of the American motif and GM shed most of its subsidiaries. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	25	3572	3755	The Detroit Three were able to revive their fortunes in the 1990s with the development of sport utility vehicles and the rising popularity of trucks, but the profits were short-lived. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	26	3765	3930	Japanese automakers responded to Detroit's hulking truck-based suvs with smaller, more efficient car-based crossovers suvs and once again GM was slow to follow suit. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	27	3940	4058	When fuel prices began to rise and consumers shifted away from gasoline guzzles, GM's sales -- and profits -- crashed. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	28	4068	4138	The latest round of plant closures and layoffs began in November 2005. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	29	4148	4272	Since then, GM's US workforce has been slashed by nearly half from 160,000 at the end of 2004 to 83,315 at the end of April. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	30	4282	4495	The real problem, analysts say, is that GM waited too long to address the ballooning "legacy costs" associated with supporting generations of retirees with a US market share that had slipped to 26 percent by 2005. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	31	4505	4619	GM's costs for each vehicle built were about 2,000 to 2,500 dollars higher than the US plants of its Asian rivals. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	32	4629	4839	GM was able to reach a historic deal with the United Auto Workers union to slash labor costs in 2007, but only after spending 103 billion dollars to fund pensions and retiree health care from 1993 through 2007. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0410	33	4849	4977	And though GM has managed to dramatically improve its product quality and offerings in recent years, it was too little too late. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	0	58	96	Can GM succeed as 'Government Motors'? 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	1	174	359	General Motors, readying a massive bankruptcy filing backed by billions in public funds, faces a complex set of challenges as a virtually nationalized "Government Motors," analysts say. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	2	369	576	With the US government expected to hold as much as 72.5 percent of the new firm that would emerge from bankruptcy, analysts say a big question is whether GM can concentrate on the difficult auto marketplace. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	3	586	741	"The tricky part is to leave day-to-day management to the executives of the company," said Jeremy Anwyl, chief executive at auto research firm Edmunds.com. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	4	751	926	For the government, he said, "the temptation is to influence product decisions based on political considerations instead of market considerations, and that's always a danger." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	5	936	1131	Anwyl said it is too soon to tell how the matter will be handled by the administration of President Barack Obama, which has pledged to get out of the business as soon as GM gets back on its feet. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	6	1141	1346	David Cole, chairman of the Michigan-based Center for Automotive Research, said the government officials "are smart, dedicated people, but they can't learn the key issues of this industry in a short time." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	7	1356	1504	Cole said the government can succeed if it focuses on the goal of restoring profitability, getting taxpayer money repaid and then getting out of GM. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	8	1514	1634	"If the government forces a company to go out of step with the reality of the marketplace, that's a problem," Cole said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	9	1644	1735	"If you force the industry to build products they can't sell profitably, that's a problem." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	10	1745	1857	Cole said it was "almost unavoidable that the government will try to superimpose other agendas" on the carmaker. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	11	1867	2121	Cole and Anwyl said it would be a mistake for the government to use its role as the financial backer of GM or Chrysler to push the firms into building certain types of cars to meet environmental or other goals because consumer demands can change quickly. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	12	2131	2239	Anwyl said that with the current level of fuel prices, demand for small, fuel- efficient cars is decreasing. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	13	2240	2384	He added the Obama administration's effort to further boost fuel efficiency may hurt efforts to help Detroit automakers become profitable again. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	14	2394	2593	Peter Cohan, a management consultant and faculty member at Babson College, said GM must keep a focus on "developing a line of products that can compete with Toyota, Nissan and the rest of the world." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	15	2603	2734	"I hope the government doesn't push GM to make hybrids just for the sake of doing it but because it will be profitable strategy ... 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	16	2735	2841	They need to design and build a vehicle that will last longer than a Toyota with lower maintenance costs." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	17	2851	3017	Although some GM critics blame existing management for its woes, Anwyl said the carmaker's biggest problems stemmed from decisions made years or even decades earlier. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	18	3027	3104	"These festered over the years and GM never really confronted them," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	19	3114	3327	The US government is expected to invest an additional 30 billion dollars to help GM on top of its 20 billion dollars in loans, with most of the funds being converted to the equity stake of as much as 72.5 percent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	20	3337	3489	The US stake could be reduced by a share given to the governments of Canada and Ontario province, expected to pitch in with around nine billion dollars. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	21	3499	3647	John Pottow, a law professor and bankruptcy specialist at the University of Michigan, said the proposed ownership structure raises a lot of hackles. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	22	3657	3741	"Everyone is terrified of government mandates as opposed to market forces," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	23	3742	3833	"But I take it as face value the government saying they want to be reluctant shareholders." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	24	3843	4014	GM vice chairman Robert Lutz said the administration is taking appropriate measures to help an industry vital to the US economy, and praised Obama's Automotive Task Force. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	25	4024	4113	"Their prime goal is not to gain government control of the automobile industry," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	26	4123	4207	"They absolutely don't want that ... their number one goal is to make us successful. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0411	27	4208	4393	There finally is a realization that our country cannot remain economically strong and militarily strong and have a global impact if it’s not backed up by wealth-producing industries." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	0	58	92	GM to lose prestigious spot on Dow 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	1	168	220	General Motors' fall from grace is not yet complete. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	2	221	374	The firm's expected bankruptcy would spell its eviction from the Dow Jones coveted list of 30 top US companies, of which GM has been a pillar since 1925. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	3	384	595	Even if GM's court filing has not yet been inked, speculation is rife about which firm might take its place on the Dow Jones Industrial Average, as the former behemoth's share price tumbled 47 percent last week. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	4	605	727	GM's shares fell to 75 cents each on Friday, well below the one dollar minimum for listing on the New York-based exchange. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	5	737	814	It is a confluence of factors that means GM will suffer the same fate as AIG. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	6	815	946	In September, the insurance giant was removed from the Dow Jones index two days after its nationalization, replaced by Kraft Foods. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	7	956	1101	"Once a company files for bankruptcy protection it is disqualified from being one of the 30 Dow components," said Dow spokesperson Sybille Reitz. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	8	1111	1176	"We are aware of GM's situation and are taking steps accordingly. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	9	1177	1223	We have been following the situation closely." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	10	1233	1376	There is great competition to replace GM on the venerable list, which has served as a bellwether for US business since it was launched in 1896. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	11	1386	1514	One solution could be to replace GM with its rival Ford -- which has so far managed to escape the crisis without government aid. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	12	1524	1599	But Ford's share price is far from stellar, trading at around 5.75 dollars. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	13	1600	1740	According to John Ogg of 247wallst.com, that makes the firm -- which had previously been a member of the elite club -- an unlikely inductee. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	14	1750	1834	One of the more frequently cited names is that of Wall Street darling Goldman Sachs. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	15	1844	1971	The investment giant should be one of the first to pay back government loans, thanks to a share price of more than 144 dollars. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	16	1981	2094	Nicholas Colas, head of investment strategy at the BNY ConvergEx Group, said that makes Goldman Sachs a favorite. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	17	2104	2152	It may also have been helped by AIG's departure. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	18	2162	2326	During the AIG shakeout in September the Dow Jones group noted that the exit of one financial firm meant that that economically vital sector was under- represented. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	19	2336	2367	But there are other contenders. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	20	2368	2466	From the technology sector Apple, Google, Cisco and Oracle are mentioned as possible replacements. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	21	2476	2596	Google's candidature runs into the difficulty that its share price -- at over 400 dollars a piece -- may skew the index. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	22	2606	2676	And technology stocks are already well represented by heavyweight IBM. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	23	2686	2740	A recent poll by CNBC has further muddied the picture. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	24	2741	2807	The financial news provider asked customers who should replace GM. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	25	2808	2861	The response was Abbott Labs, a pharmaceuticals firm. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	26	2871	2919	From the biotech field, Monsanto is an outsider. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	27	2920	3046	Owen Patrick of Deutsche Bank pointed out that Monsanto was an important member of another index, the Standard and Poor's 500. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	28	3056	3211	"It is a little smaller in market cap," said BNY's Colas, "and not as well known, but its technology and competitive advantage would be unique in the Dow." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	29	3221	3309	If the GM change has been keenly anticipated, that is because change on the Dow is rare. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	30	3319	3456	Only six firms have come in this decade, with three in 2008 including Kraft -- Bank of America and Chevron replaced Altria and Honeywell.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0412	32	3589	3681	Citigroup, now trading at four dollars a share, must feel its head is on the chopping block. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	0	58	98	Malaysia's Islamic party at a crossroads 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	1	178	358	A power struggle in Malaysia's Islamic party will be put to the test in leadership polls this week which pit hardline clerics against young moderates who want to rebrand the party. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	2	368	574	The Pan-Malaysia Islamic Party (PAS) has enjoyed a surge in popularity thanks to deep public disillusionment with the Barisan Nasional coalition that has governed the multiracial country for half a century. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	3	584	813	PAS has formed an unlikely alliance with two other opposition parties which has stuck together despite wide differences in their ideologies, giving them a chance to unseat the coalition in the next elections due in several years. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	4	823	1048	But the PAS general assembly on June 5-7 will lay bare the dilemma at the party's core -- whether to swing back to its hardline roots or to put on a more moderate face to continue winning back support after some barren years. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	5	1058	1277	"The party is at a threshold -- whether it can transcend its history of catering largely to Muslims and put in place a model that everyone in the country including non-Muslims can accept," said pollster Ibrahim Suffian. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	6	1287	1507	"They need to be able to articulate issues relating to the economy, security, international trade... to not only look after your hereafter, but look after your here and today," said Ibrahim, from Merdeka Centre research. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	7	1517	1730	Some 60 percent of Malaysians are Muslim Malays, but the population includes large ethnic Chinese and Indian communities, and if PAS wants to break out beyond its niche it needs to attract support from minorities. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	8	1740	1929	Curiously, despite pushing for the creation of an Islamic state and the introduction of "hudud" laws like chopping off thieves' hands, PAS has won the trust and support of many non-Muslims. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	9	1939	2151	Chinese and Indian voters have enthusiastically supported PAS candidates in seats where they stood for the Pakatan Rakyat opposition alliance, and thousands have joined PAS "Supporters' Clubs" around the country. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	10	2161	2298	Much of the attraction stems from PAS's reputation as a clean party untainted by the corruption which is endemic in the ruling coalition. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	11	2308	2495	And in northern Kelantan state, where it has long been in power, minorities have few complaints and are not obliged to observe local bylaws that discourage skimpy clothing and high heels. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	12	2505	2714	Reforms introduced before landmark 2008 elections, when the Pakatan Rakyat snatched a third of parliamentary seats in an unprecedented performance, reversed a decline that had seen PAS decimated in 2004 polls. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	13	2724	2920	"They stopped talking about wanting to impose stricter sharia laws and they had much more moderate faces in the party, people who were professionals and able to converse in English," said Ibrahim. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	14	2930	3136	But this rebranding exercise is now in jeopardy with a vote for top leadership posts, including the deputy presidency, which will see a clash between incumbent Nasharuddin Mat Isa and challenger Husam Musa. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	15	3146	3332	Husam is an economist who typifies the party's new generation of educated professionals, while Nasharuddin is closely identified with the party's conservative president Abdul Hadi Awang. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	16	3342	3535	Husam is an ally of PAS's iconic spiritual leader Nik Abdul Aziz Nik Mat, a quirky figure who is a highly respected religious leader and also a big supporter of opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	17	3545	3741	Nasharuddin meanwhile played a leading role in "secret" talks last year with the ruling party UMNO -- which leads the Barisan Nasional coalition -- that were hugely controversial within the party. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	18	3751	3926	Observers say that if Nasharuddin retains his post, the fragile bonds between the opposition partners will begin to erode, jeopardising its ability to challenge the coalition. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	19	3936	3964	"PAS is at a crossroads now. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	20	3965	4133	This meeting will see whether PAS is inclined to have a good relationship with UMNO or have a good relationship with its opposition partners," a party insider told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	21	4143	4344	He said that a rebuke to Husam would also send out a negative message to non- Muslims that it remains the "party of the ulamas", the elderly cohort of clerics who have historically dominated the party. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	22	4354	4465	"As a political party PAS has to go with the (reform) approach, that which is accepted by the Malaysian people. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0413	23	4466	4579	During the last general election PAS had a lot of support from non-Muslims and it has to maintain that," he said.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	0	58	98	Malaysia's Islamic party at a crossroads 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	1	178	358	A power struggle in Malaysia's Islamic party will be put to the test in leadership polls this week which pit hardline clerics against young moderates who want to rebrand the party. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	2	368	574	The Pan-Malaysia Islamic Party (PAS) has enjoyed a surge in popularity thanks to deep public disillusionment with the Barisan Nasional coalition that has governed the multiracial country for half a century. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	3	584	813	PAS has formed an unlikely alliance with two other opposition parties which has stuck together despite wide differences in their ideologies, giving them a chance to unseat the coalition in the next elections due in several years. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	4	823	1048	But the PAS general assembly on June 5-7 will lay bare the dilemma at the party's core -- whether to swing back to its hardline roots or to put on a more moderate face to continue winning back support after some barren years. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	5	1058	1277	"The party is at a threshold -- whether it can transcend its history of catering largely to Muslims and put in place a model that everyone in the country including non-Muslims can accept," said pollster Ibrahim Suffian. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	6	1287	1507	"They need to be able to articulate issues relating to the economy, security, international trade... to not only look after your hereafter, but look after your here and today," said Ibrahim, from Merdeka Centre research. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	7	1517	1730	Some 60 percent of Malaysians are Muslim Malays, but the population includes large ethnic Chinese and Indian communities, and if PAS wants to break out beyond its niche it needs to attract support from minorities. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	8	1740	1929	Curiously, despite pushing for the creation of an Islamic state and the introduction of "hudud" laws like chopping off thieves' hands, PAS has won the trust and support of many non-Muslims. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	9	1939	2151	Chinese and Indian voters have enthusiastically supported PAS candidates in seats where they stood for the Pakatan Rakyat opposition alliance, and thousands have joined PAS "Supporters' Clubs" around the country. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	10	2161	2298	Much of the attraction stems from PAS's reputation as a clean party untainted by the corruption which is endemic in the ruling coalition. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	11	2308	2495	And in northern Kelantan state, where it has long been in power, minorities have few complaints and are not obliged to observe local bylaws that discourage skimpy clothing and high heels. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	12	2505	2714	Reforms introduced before landmark 2008 elections, when the Pakatan Rakyat snatched a third of parliamentary seats in an unprecedented performance, reversed a decline that had seen PAS decimated in 2004 polls. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	13	2724	2920	"They stopped talking about wanting to impose stricter sharia laws and they had much more moderate faces in the party, people who were professionals and able to converse in English," said Ibrahim. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	14	2930	3136	But this rebranding exercise is now in jeopardy with a vote for top leadership posts, including the deputy presidency, which will see a clash between incumbent Nasharuddin Mat Isa and challenger Husam Musa. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	15	3146	3332	Husam is an economist who typifies the party's new generation of educated professionals, while Nasharuddin is closely identified with the party's conservative president Abdul Hadi Awang. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	16	3342	3535	Husam is an ally of PAS's iconic spiritual leader Nik Abdul Aziz Nik Mat, a quirky figure who is a highly respected religious leader and also a big supporter of opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	17	3545	3741	Nasharuddin meanwhile played a leading role in "secret" talks last year with the ruling party UMNO -- which leads the Barisan Nasional coalition -- that were hugely controversial within the party. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	18	3751	3926	Observers say that if Nasharuddin retains his post, the fragile bonds between the opposition partners will begin to erode, jeopardising its ability to challenge the coalition. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	19	3936	3964	"PAS is at a crossroads now. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	20	3965	4133	This meeting will see whether PAS is inclined to have a good relationship with UMNO or have a good relationship with its opposition partners," a party insider told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	21	4143	4344	He said that a rebuke to Husam would also send out a negative message to non- Muslims that it remains the "party of the ulamas", the elderly cohort of clerics who have historically dominated the party. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	22	4354	4465	"As a political party PAS has to go with the (reform) approach, that which is accepted by the Malaysian people. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0415	23	4466	4579	During the last general election PAS had a lot of support from non-Muslims and it has to maintain that," he said.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	1	180	375	Described by inmates as a "hell" where beatings are common and disease is rife, Myanmar's Insein Prison, where Aung San Suu Kyi is on trial, is the brutal symbol of the ruling junta's repression. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	2	385	590	The Nobel laureate has spent the past three weeks incarcerated in a so-called "guest house" at the jail on the outskirts of Yangon while her trial takes place behind closed doors at the notorious compound. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	3	600	713	Her party has expressed concerns for her health after she suffered leg cramps in recent days while at the prison. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	4	714	764	The authorities say she is receiving medical care. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	5	774	995	But if Aung San Suu Kyi has been kept in relatively bearable conditions at the prison -- which was built by former colonial power Britain -- for hundreds of other political prisoners it is the heart of Myanmar's darkness. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	6	1005	1050	"It's like a hell where people really suffer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	7	1051	1190	It's some kind of silent 'killing field,'" Bo Kyi, who spent seven years in the jail following a failed student uprising in 1988, told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	8	1200	1335	Several political prisoners told of how they suffered bruising weeks-long interrogations at the hands of the junta's jailers at Insein. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	9	1345	1529	Bo Kyi said during one round of questioning he was whipped with a rubber cord as he lay on his stomach and counted 150 lashes before he lost consciousness and awoke in a solitary cell. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	10	1539	1671	He said he was then forced to assume different positions for hour-long periods while shackled in chains with a bar between his legs. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	11	1681	1864	The heavily secured Insein is home to many of the 2,100 political prisoners which the United Nations says are held in Myanmar's prisons, often on spurious sentences of up to 60 years. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	12	1874	2087	At least 139 political detainees have died in detention in the country since 1988, several of them in Insein, according to the Assistance Association for Political Prisoners of Burma (AAPPB), co-founded by Bo Kyi. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	13	2097	2317	Details of conditions inside the secretive jail emerge mostly from former prisoners, although Tomas Okea Quintana, the UN Special Rapporteur on Myanmar, visited the prison for four hours in February and met five inmates. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	14	2327	2428	He said after his visit that many detainees suffered from a lack of medical care during imprisonment. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	15	2438	2640	Former prisoner Aung Myo Naing, who spent more than eight years there, said that each cell in Insein is 8 by 11 feet (2.5 by 3.5 metres), furnished with two bamboo mats and two uncovered toilet buckets. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	16	2650	2832	"Insein Prison is a deadly torture camp," the 41-year-old said, describing one period of about 45 days when he was kept in solitary confinement and forbidden to read, write or bathe. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	17	2842	3032	Past prisoners have described novel methods of communicating during these times, scratching messages to one another on cigarette filter papers and feeding them through holes in prison walls. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	18	3042	3166	Inmates are given 15 minutes outside of the cell daily to shower, but they have no soap and no spare clothes to change into. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	19	3176	3381	Many prisoners are starving -- their rations of food consist of boiled water with a few sparse vegetables, fish paste and occasional rations of meat along with overcooked rice, while water is not purified. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	20	3391	3544	The conditions mean that diseases such as tuberculosis and hepatitis B are rife, while joint pains, eyesight problems and mental illness are commonplace. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	21	3554	3585	But access to a doctor is rare. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	22	3595	3775	"They give you aspirins and another drug for sneezing, whatever illness you've got," said Aung Myo Thein, whose elder brother was also imprisoned and now suffers severe depression. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	23	3785	3849	Due to dirty needles, medical treatment can itself be hazardous. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	24	3859	4086	Last year media watchdog Reporters Without Borders said that poet Aung Than, a member of Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy, was probably infected with the HIV virus when he was forcibly injected in Insein prison hospital. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	25	4096	4251	Many other prominent prisoners have been denied access to healthcare and have been moved since October 2008 to jails hundreds of miles from their families. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0419	26	4261	4472	The International Committee of the Red Cross made its last visit to Insein Prison in November 2005, and two months later suspended its prison visits saying it could not fulfil its independent, impartial mandate.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	0	58	113	India economy headed higher, reforms in sight: analysts 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	1	190	367	India's economy is on the upswing with eyes now keenly focused on July's planned budget for new market-opening moves by the freshly re-elected Congress government, analysts say. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	2	377	596	The country logged unexpectedly strong 5.8 percent growth in the final quarter to March 2009, against forecasts of 5.0 percent, figures late last week showed, prompting analysts to say the economy had turned the corner. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	3	606	758	"We see a new growth cycle taking shape with the first stop seven percent and then eight percent," said Rajeev Malik, economist at Macquarie Securities. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	4	768	873	India's economy expanded by 6.7 percent in the year to March 2009, down from nine percent a year earlier. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	5	883	1110	But the country of nearly 1.2 billion people is performing far better than many others caught in the global slump, thanks to its vast, resilient domestic market, hefty government spending and aggressive rate cuts, analysts say. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	6	1120	1347	Foreign capital is pouring back into India with the benchmark Sensex share index near a nine-month high of 14,625 following a spurt in May after the Congress party was swept back to power with its biggest seat haul in 18 years. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	7	1357	1509	The strong mandate allows the Congress to govern without the support of the communists who propped up the government in parliament during its last term. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	8	1519	1733	Economists called the Congress win a "game changer" for the economy because it raises hopes of political stability for the next five years and the introduction of economic reforms that had been blocked by the Left. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	9	1743	1997	There has already been a flurry of announcements by new ministers promising such moves as loosening state-controlled fuel pump prices, which would help refinery profits, and cutting mobile call rates to propel India's explosively growing cellular sector. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	10	2007	2198	Economic growth is forecast at around six percent in the first half of the year and closer to seven percent in the second amid "green shoots" signs such as higher car sales and cement output. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	11	2208	2264	Next year, economists expect expansion of eight percent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	12	2274	2454	"We expect a pick-up in economic activity from lower borrowing costs and higher government spending which is feeding through the system," said Shubhada  Rao, economist at Yes Bank. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	13	2464	2612	In another positive sign, the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry (FICCI) announced Saturday a sharp upturn in business optimism. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	14	2622	2839	Some 57 percent of 300 firms polled in the final quarter to March declared economic conditions were "moderately to substantially" better -- up from the nine percent in the previous quarter who reported an improvement. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	15	2849	2977	"Companies are looking forward to a recovery on the basis of their order books and performance," FICCI economist Anjan Roy said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	16	2987	3207	Economists are now focused on the budget that Finance Minister Pranab Mukherjee has promised to present in the first week of July to see what steps he will take to open up India's still relatively inward-looking economy. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	17	3217	3405	Mukherjee said last week the government would press ahead with some long stymied reforms "in the financial sector and real economy" to make it more competitive and draw foreign investment. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	18	3415	3598	The government may privatise some state-owned firms and raise  foreign-ownership caps in insurance and aviation as well as possibly broadening overseas investment access in retailing. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	19	3608	3855	But Mukherjee said his "top priority" was "reviving the growth momentum" and helping the poor and he would step up spending even if this meant scant progress in closing India's yawning fiscal deficit, which at 6.2 percent is at a seven- year peak. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	20	3865	3996	HSBC economist Robert Prior Wandesforde forecast no "big bang" reforms in a country where economic changes can provoke huge debate. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0425	21	4006	4131	But "even if they (the government) do a few things, the multiplier effect will be quite significant," said Macquarie's Malik. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	0	58	86	Foreign investors eye Angola 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	1	160	344	In the lobby bar of one of Luanda's few decent hotels, suited businessmen sit in deep leather armchairs waiting for a meeting in the oil-rich country which could change their fortunes. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	2	354	468	"Angola is one of the last great emerging market opportunities," one European man told AFP between sips of whisky. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	3	478	617	"I don't care about the logistical problems as long as the solutions and rewards are there -- I'm in this for the long term to make money." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	4	627	831	Thanks to high oil prices and a peacetime construction frenzy, Angola has enjoyed annual double-digit growth since a 27-year civil war ended in 2002 to become one of the world's fastest growing economies. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	5	841	1027	Growth is set to slow this year, but interest from international investors has not abated with a recent flurry of high profile trade delegations, all hoping to get a piece of the action. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	6	1037	1224	The government's response to falling commodity prices, which threaten public spending aimed at Angola's poor majority, is diversification into areas such as agriculture and manufacturing. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	7	1234	1423	Until now, Angola's main foreign players have been Brazilian and Portuguese firms, and Chinese companies helped along by close ties and credit lines believed to exceed five billion dollars. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	8	1433	1654	But along with visits from the United States, France and South Korea in the past month, there have also been business forums in Rome and Cairo and state visits by President Jose Eduardo dos Santos to Germany and Portugal. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	9	1664	1760	Last week a trade agreement was signed with US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton in Washington. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	10	1770	1929	Among the recent American delegation was Delta Air Lines which hopes to launch the first direct scheduled flight from the United States to Luanda in September. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	11	1939	2087	"There's no question, Angola is a very strong market and there is a lot of potential," the airline's government affairs advisor Scott Yohe told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	12	2097	2276	"The amount of time it takes to get to Angola from the US, via Europe or via South Africa, has an impact on trade and the new flight will definitely be a catalyst for investment." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	13	2286	2371	Dubai-based Emirates starts flying three times a week from Luanda to Dubai in August. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	14	2381	2506	"Angola is a country which is really moving," explained Nigel Page, senior vice president of Emirates in Americas and Africa. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	15	2516	2670	"We predict that there will be a lot of business exchanges between Luanda and Dubai and this route will channel more companies into Angola from the east." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	16	2680	2871	There is already plenty of Asian investment in Angola, particularly from China which holds a number of key construction contracts, including four 2010 Africa Cup of Nations football stadiums. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	17	2881	3114	China's interest in Angola has aroused concern in the west, especially as a number of the loans have been oil backed, but Alex Vines, of the London-based think tank Chatham House, believes the Sino-Angolan relationship may be waning. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	18	3124	3245	"From a geo-strategic point of view, Angola wants to woo lots of different investment, not just from China," he told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	19	3255	3389	"And that's why we've seen Dos Santos making these high profile visits to Europe and these other trade trips being invited to Angola." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	20	3399	3613	Despite predicting a three-percent contraction in 2009, World Bank economist Ricardo Gazel said: "Angola's economy is still in a much better position than most and medium and long term, the prospects are very good. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	21	3623	3779	"There is a lot of investment interest, particularly in the non-petroleum sector which is good for diversifying the economy and for the economy as a whole." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	22	3789	3899	For businesses hoping to break into the Angolan market however, it's not easy and good contacts go a long way. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	23	3909	4087	The World Bank's Doing Business Report ranks Angola as one of the hardest places to set up a company with 68 days needed to start a business, although this has halved since 2008. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0426	24	4097	4239	But, big on capital if low on know-how, Angola has been spreading the word about investment opportunities and it seems the world is listening.
