AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	0	58	109	Bordeaux bets on top quality but cheap 2008 vintage 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	1	193	375	After months of gloom, Bordeaux wine traders are hoping the 2008 vintage will revive the market after steep price cuts and rave reviews from the world's most influential connoisseur. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	2	385	505	The southwestern French region's rarest wines are sold every spring as a futures commodity, 12 months prior to bottling. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	3	506	584	With the world gripped by recession, many had been fearing financial disaster. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	4	594	811	The futures sale only concerns a tiny percentage of the 800 million bottles the Bordeaux region produces annually, but the prices of the top 20 wines help determine the public perception of the quality of the vintage. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	5	821	1038	This year, the big wine estates brought prices down sharply, opening the way for traders to target middle market wine drinkers after a period when the finest wines were priced for sale to only the richest speculators. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	6	1048	1243	As Patrick Bernard, owner of wine merchant powerhouse Millesima, explained: "If the top 20 wines double or triple their prices as they did in 2005, all of Bordeaux wine is perceived as expensive. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	7	1253	1358	"The first wine on the market was Angelus, one of those 20 wines, and they cut their price by 40 percent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	8	1359	1474	A few days later, the First Growths came out with a 45 percent decrease and then Yquem with a 65 percent decrease." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	9	1484	1556	Other premium wines were released at the same time to maintain momentum. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	10	1557	1645	Leoville Barton dropped its ex-cellar price to 23 euros and sold out within a few hours. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	11	1655	1862	"It was much better than I expected," said Lilian Barton, co-owner of the legendary estates Chateaux Leoville Barton and Langoa Barton, and director of her family wine merchant, Les Vins Fins Anthony Barton. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	12	1872	2070	In addition to dropping their prices, the chateaux had hoped to demonstrate their independence from US wine critic Robert Parker, nicknamed the "Million Dollar Nose" for his influence on the market. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	13	2080	2282	Parker is a champion of Bordeaux's wines, but many in the industry feel that he wields too much power with his rankings, and three-quarters of the wines were put on sale before he had given his verdict. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	14	2292	2358	The demonstration of defiance was only partly successful, at best. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	15	2368	2494	Several sources said that sales prior to the release of Parker's ratings, with the exception of a few star buys, were subdued. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	16	2495	2565	The tempo changed when Parker awarded the vintage spectacular ratings. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	17	2575	2614	"The buyers went berserk," said Barton. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	18	2624	2720	Clients who had pleaded poverty in early April suddenly found the wherewithal to buy on futures. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	19	2730	2943	Despite annoyance with the fickle importers, Barton, Anson, Bernard and others were relieved to see the return of traditional customers who had been pushed out of the market in recent years by skyrocketing prices. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	20	2953	3102	The vintage was very good and there was a dramatic drop in price -- buyers are stocking up for customers who buy wine to drink rather than to invest. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	21	3112	3177	"This was the vintage to buy for the consumer," enthused Bernard. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	22	3187	3359	Unlike nearly all of the other 400 wine merchants, Millesima, with annual revenues of 52 million euros, sells directly to the consumer in 11 European countries and America. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	23	3369	3419	"Direct sales to European consumers has been good. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	24	3420	3513	There's no currency problem and they haven't been able to afford it over the last few years." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	25	3523	3717	Bernard will buy 35,000 cases this year, a 10 percent increase over last year even though most chateaux are offering customers only 80 percent of their usual allocations because of a small crop. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	26	3727	3923	While the 2008 futures campaign is slowly drawing to a close, there is little doubt that for many it succeeded in resuscitating not only sales but the image of Bordeaux wine as a consumer product. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0429	27	3933	4115	Already merchants and winegrowers are looking forward to Vinexpo, the International Wine and Spirits Exhibition held from June 21 to 25, with 45,000 professionals expected to attend. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	0	58	115	Eurozone interest rate locked, new steps on tap: analysts 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	1	192	387	The main eurozone interest rate is probably locked in at 1.0 percent for now, but credit flows remain weak and the European Central Bank will detail this week new ways to get money flowing again. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	2	397	615	The ECB will also release Thursday its latest staff forecasts for growth and inflation in the 16-nation bloc, with a downward revision likely for the former owing to a disastrous first quarter in its leading economies. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	3	625	807	With interest rates most likely on hold for a while, "the focus has shifted to any developments regarding unconventional policies," said Capital Economics economist Jennifer McKeown. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	4	817	1065	The ECB has already said it will buy 60 billion euros' (85 billion dollars') worth of covered, or collateralised, bonds, a move that should help restore cash flows in French, German and Spanish markets where such instruments are traded most widely. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	5	1075	1144	Details are expected after a meeting of the bank's governing council. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	6	1154	1377	But the amount corresponds to just 0.6 percent of the eurozone's gross domestic product, McKeown noted, whereas bolder moves by the US Federal Reserve and Bank of England are worth around 10 percent of their respective GDP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	7	1387	1584	It also remains to be seen whether the ECB will "sterilise" the purchases by issuing its own debt or selling other assets, or whether it will just print new money, a move that could fuel inflation. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	8	1594	1800	The bank's priority is to keep inflation just below 2.0 percent, but it now faces the prospect of a broad-based fall in prices that could end in a deflationary spiral which could strangle economic activity. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	9	1810	1999	If businesses and individuals become convinced that prices will fall further, they postpone purchases, causing production to fall and raising unemployment, which can depress prices further. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	10	2009	2233	Eurozone inflation hit a record low of zero in May, European Union statistics showed, and will likely turn negative in coming months owing to comparisons with the same period last year when oil prices spiked to record highs. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	11	2243	2398	But UniCredit economist Marco Valli said: "We don't think the ECB will be overly impressed" by the development, which has been forecast for several months. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	12	2408	2616	ECB president Jean-Claude Trichet has stressed that short term price volatility is not a factor in the bank's decisions, and with oil prices on the rise again, a deflationary episode is unlikely to last long. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	13	2626	2753	"The recent strong rally in oil prices makes the inflation picture more uncertain than just a couple of weeks ago," Valli said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	14	2763	2847	"The central bank will continue to see the risk of deflation as very low," he added. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	15	2857	3061	The ECB can also point to indications that the eurozone's first recession has probably passed its trough even though the European Commission still expects the economy to contract by 1.9 percent this year. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	16	3071	3193	That leaves the thorny problem of credit growth, which according to the bank's figures continued to slow sharply in April. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	17	3203	3345	"There is no easing in the very tight credit conditions that are facing companies and individuals," noted Howard Archer at IHS Global Insight. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	18	3355	3530	"Tighter credit conditions are a serious handicap to recovery prospects in the eurozone," he said, and raise pressure on the ECB "to take additional 'non- standard' measures." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0430	19	3540	3729	Commerzbank analyst Rainer Guntermann felt "the ECB has not yet closed the door to more easing measures," but that an expansion of the already announced bond purchases in June was unlikely. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	0	58	87	Germany rescues Opel, for now 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	1	161	356	Germany has ensured that Opel's tens of thousands of workers will still have a job on Monday when its once-mighty US parent General Motors, as is expected, makes history and files for bankruptcy. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	2	366	578	But Chancellor Angela Merkel's decision to support with taxpayers' money a Kremlin-backed rescue may come back to haunt her, and could fail to prevent Opel crashing and burning further down the road, experts say. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	3	588	635	"All this seems to rest on a very fragile base. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	4	636	766	Let's say there is a 60 or 70 percent chance that it won't work," Juergen Pieper, an automotive analyst at Metzler Bank, told AFP. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	5	776	1000	In a mammoth effort over recent months climaxing in a frenzy of activity last week, the German government agreed in the early hours of Saturday morning to back a takeover of Opel by a consortium formed around Canada's Magna. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	6	1010	1109	Under the deal, GM would keep 35 percent of the company and Opel's workers would retain 10 percent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	7	1110	1222	Magna, which makes auto parts, would hold a 20 percent stake and state-owned Russian lender Sberbank 35 percent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	8	1232	1454	Government sources told AFP that Germany would act as guarantor for around three billion euros (4.2 billion dollars) worth of loans, and the government would also itself make an emergency loan of 1.5 billion euros to Opel. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	9	1464	1650	Magna meanwhile, which until recently was relatively unknown outside the auto industry, has pledged to cough up 300 million euros to keep the cash-starved Opel alive in the coming weeks. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	10	1660	1874	The Canadian firm, which thrashed out an eleventh-hour agreement with GM executives in a luxury Berlin hotel on Friday, has pledged to keep all Opel's German factories open and limit job cuts there to around 2,500. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	11	1884	2095	But across Europe as a whole, where GM employs some 50,000 people including 7,000 in Spain and 4,700 at Britain's Vauxhall, the picture may be less rosy with Magna saying it plans to lay off one in five workers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	12	2105	2331	Last week Germany came under pressure from Britain and Belgium not to save German jobs at the expense of workers elsewhere, and on Saturday Britain's biggest trade union Unite voiced concern about the fate of Vauxhall workers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	13	2341	2579	It was also unclear whether Magna's intention to start making Opel cars at a factory in Russia owned by precious metals tycoon Oleg Deripaska's GAZ automaker would mean some production will be taken away from plants in the European Union. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	14	2589	2738	Russian involvement also raises eyebrows because it strengthens the already strong business ties -- most notably in gas -- between Berlin and Moscow. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	15	2739	2804	Critics say that these ties make Germany too soft on the Kremlin. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	16	2814	2919	For analysts, it was September's elections in Germany that helped win Merkel over to Russian involvement. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	17	2929	3044	"Money doesn't smell at election time," said Andrew Wilson at the European Council of Foreign Relations think tank. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	18	3054	3271	Magna and its Russian backers have their work cut out making the deal work, with Opel part of a global automotive industry that was already facing huge challenges even before the world economy hit the skids last year. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	19	3281	3466	Frank Schwope, an analyst at Germany's NordLB bank, predicted that the Canadian- Russian investors "will try everything, and then fail and Opel will be insolvent in two or three years." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	20	3476	3652	Magna also has very little experience making cars -- unlike Fiat, which also wanted to snap up Opel but then got cold feet -- and the financial details of the deal are unclear. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	21	3662	3725	Merkel admitted on Saturday that the road ahead is a rocky one. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	22	3735	3851	"For Opel and Magna, the work is now just beginning and there are several difficulties still to overcome," she said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0431	23	3861	4075	But cynics say that for the chancellor and her partners in the governing coalition, even if Opel does end up collapsing further down the road, it is mission accomplished: Opel will not be issue in September's vote.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0432	1	180	353	General Ould Abdel Aziz, who toppled Mauritania's government last year, said that no deal was near on delaying a controversial election scheduled to be held later this week.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	0	58	111	Progress in fighting lung cancer at specialist summit 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	1	195	400	Cancer specialists, gathered for an annual meeting, are reporting progress in the fight against lung cancer, the most common and deadliest form of cancer, but little progress in treating colorectal cancer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	2	410	635	Doctors and researchers at the 45th gathering of the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) -- the world's main cancer conference -- on Saturday learned of two studies showing progress in the battle against lung cancer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	3	645	786	The first study showed how the combination of two anti-cancer treatments following standard chemotherapy can slow the advance of lung cancer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	4	796	1002	Patients treated with a combination of Tarceva, sold by the Swiss drugmaker Roche, and Avastin, a drug by Roche's Genentech unit, saw their cancer growth slow more than a control group treated with Avastin. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	5	1012	1108	More than 750 patients were randomized to receive Avastin and a placebo, or Avastin and Tarceva. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	6	1109	1302	Those in the Tarceva group survived an average of 4.8 months before the cancer started growing again, compared to 3.7 months for the control group, said Vincent Miller, the study's main author. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	7	1312	1446	The numbers translated to a 29 percent reduced risk of disease progression for patients who took a combination of Tarceva and Avastin. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	8	1456	1700	"This is the first study to show that adding erlotinib (Tarceva) to maintenance therapy with bevacizumab (Avastin) delays disease progression in patients who have already received bevacizumab as part of their initial chemotherapy," said Miller. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	9	1710	1855	A second study with 663 patients with advance lung cancer were given the drug Alimta, from US pharmaceutical Eli Lilly, which blocks cell growth. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	10	1865	2029	Preliminary results showed that patients who took the drug lived 26 percent longer compared to a control group that took a placebo: 13.4 months against 10.6 months. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	11	2039	2136	As in the first study, all the patients had already received four standard chemotherapy sessions. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	12	2146	2308	"This study will change the overall standard of care," said Chandra Belani, the deputy director of the Penn State Cancer Institute, as she presented the research. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	13	2318	2567	"Maintenance therapy with Alimta (permetrexed) offers a new paradigm for patients who have advanced lung cancer, because it has a low toxicity and can be given on an ongoing basis over a prolonged period of time to extend patients' lives," she said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	14	2577	2743	However there were few advances to report in the fight against colorectal cancer, the fourth most common in the United States and the second deadliest type of cancer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	15	2753	3028	Research on 2,710 patients with Phase Three colorectal cancer taking the drug Avastine along with standard chemotherapy treatment showed no difference in the survival rate or the recurrence of the tumor after three and a half years when compared to those not taking the drug. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0437	16	3038	3285	Another study conducted in Italy among 747 patients with advanced colorectal cancer showed that the drug Eloxatine from the French firm Sanofi did not reduce the size of the tumor when combined with standard treatment used ahead of cancer surgery.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	0	58	108	Key Tiananmen dissident still defiant, 20 years on 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	1	183	383	Former top Chinese Communist official Bao Tong was purged for supporting the 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square, but he says his frustrations with the system started decades before. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	2	393	617	"China's people have wasted 60 years," Bao, now one of the country's top political dissidents, told AFP recently -- before authorities moved him out of Beijing to wait out Thursday's 20th anniversary of the deadly crackdown. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	3	627	770	His harsh assessment of the history of the People's Republic of China, founded in October 1949, is one few ordinary Chinese would dare to make. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	4	780	887	But the 76-year-old Bao, once a top aide to former Chinese leader Zhao Ziyang, is not your average citizen. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	5	897	1099	He has spent the past 20 years either in jail, under house arrest or facing other restrictions in his small west Beijing flat, just one block from a major road where protesters battled tanks and troops. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	6	1109	1317	He sees no sign of political openness on the horizon and says Beijing's failure to come clean on the events of June 3-4, 1989 and give justice to victims has been a key factor stunting democratic development. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	7	1327	1367	"It has had a seriously negative impact. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	8	1368	1504	It has made China a country with no voice.... a country in which no one can demand fairness," he said in the interview at his apartment. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	9	1514	1741	"I am a sample on display," Bao says with a smirk, charging the government only allows foreign journalists to interview him to give the impression of openness, while preventing anything he says from being disseminated in China. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	10	1751	1937	Bao was dragged down along with Zhao, who was ousted from his position as general secretary of the Communist Party for sympathising with the student protesters who had rallied for weeks. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	11	1947	2046	Zhao had opposed the use of force against the demonstrators, but was overruled by party hardliners. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	12	2047	2115	Hundreds, and possibly thousands, were killed in the army crackdown. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	13	2125	2223	Bao, who once directed a top Communist party political reform office, is still lean and energetic. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	14	2233	2391	He now spends much of his time doing interviews with or fielding calls from foreign media on a phone whose ring tone is the Disney theme "It's a Small World." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	15	2401	2587	Bao said China's current leaders bear no blame for what happened in Tiananmen Square -- and could earn great praise both at home and abroad on this anniversary by being more forthcoming. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	16	2597	2723	"They are still the nation's leaders and I hope they can openly tell the Chinese people and the world what happened," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	17	2733	2879	But the party's unwillingness to admit any mistakes will prevent that and the Chinese people are too intimidated to demand such honesty, he added. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	18	2889	3114	Much of the blame lies with the rest of the world for refusing to push China to heal the wounds, said Bao, adding that other countries were increasingly hesitant to rile China due to its growing economic and diplomatic clout. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	19	3124	3322	"Not wanting to offend China means they cannot help China, cannot help China's people attain their own rights, and cannot help the world community gain a reliable, stable, peaceful member," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	20	3332	3359	"This is not a good thing." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	21	3369	3538	As the Communist Party gears up to celebrate the 60th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China on October 1, Bao said there was little to celebrate. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	22	3548	3689	The party wasted a lifetime with collectivisation of the economy launched in 1953, only to come full circle with today's run-away capitalism. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	23	3699	3742	"(We) have come back to the original point. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	24	3743	3813	The work of 1.3 billion people has been wasted for 56 years," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	25	3823	3880	"This is a crime greater than (the Tiananmen crackdown)." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	26	3890	4053	Bao expressed delight with the May release in English of Zhao's memoirs, put together from secret tape recordings the deposed leader made while under house arrest. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	27	4054	4117	His son, Bao Pu, is publishing the Chinese version of the book. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	28	4127	4245	He said he hoped the book, likely to be banned in China, could somehow be distributed in the country and spark debate. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	29	4255	4416	But he admitted the ghosts of Tiananmen would not likely be laid to rest any time soon due to the nature of a government for which he wishes he had never worked. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	30	4426	4482	"I regret that I only realised all of this 20 years ago. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	31	4483	4545	Why couldn't I have realised it 40 years ago or 60 years ago?" 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0441	32	4546	4558	he lamented.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	0	58	112	Tiananmen: Six weeks of protests, and then a crackdown 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	1	187	362	In April 1989, young Chinese with dreams of democracy staged an unprecedented wave of protests after the death of former Communist Party leader Hu Yaobang, a popular reformer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	2	372	503	The Tiananmen movement lasted six weeks before being violently quashed by the army, leaving hundreds, and possibly thousands, dead. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	3	513	551	Here is a timeline of the main events: 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	4	561	571	April 1989 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	5	581	649	- 15: Death of Hu Yaobang, who had been dismissed two years earlier. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	6	659	776	- 17: First student protest on Tiananmen Square, to lay a wreath in honour of Hu, adorned with pro-democracy slogans. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	7	786	904	- 18: The students issue a list of demands to the government that includes freedom of speech and democratic elections. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	8	914	1043	- 22: Hu's official funeral takes place at the Great Hall of the People on Tiananmen Square, where 200,000 students are gathered. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	9	1053	1268	- 25: Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, says the protest movement seeks to topple the Communist Party -- a claim that forms the basis of an explosive editorial in the official People's Daily newspaper the next day. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	10	1278	1428	- 27: Huge student demonstrations take place in Beijing, and protests erupt across the country, including in towns that had been calm until that time. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	11	1438	1441	May 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	12	1451	1580	- 4: The anniversary of the patriotic movement of May 4, 1919 triggers a new mass demonstration in Beijing and in 50 other towns. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	13	1581	1642	The head of the Communist Party, Zhao Ziyang, urges dialogue. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	14	1652	1729	- 13: Students launch the occupation of Tiananmen Square and a hunger strike. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0443	15	1739	1868	- 15: A historic visit by then Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev for the normalisation of Sino-Soviet ties is completely disrupted.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0445	0	58	112	Tiananmen: Six weeks of protests, and then a crackdown 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0445	1	187	362	In April 1989, young Chinese with dreams of democracy staged an unprecedented wave of protests after the death of former Communist Party leader Hu Yaobang, a popular reformer. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0445	2	372	503	The Tiananmen movement lasted six weeks before being violently quashed by the army, leaving hundreds, and possibly thousands, dead. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0445	3	513	551	Here is a timeline of the main events: 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0445	4	561	571	April 1989 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0445	5	581	649	- 15: Death of Hu Yaobang, who had been dismissed two years earlier. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0445	6	659	776	- 17: First student protest on Tiananmen Square, to lay a wreath in honour of Hu, adorned with pro-democracy slogans. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0445	7	786	904	- 18: The students issue a list of demands to the government that includes freedom of speech and democratic elections. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0445	8	914	1043	- 22: Hu's official funeral takes place at the Great Hall of the People on Tiananmen Square, where 200,000 students are gathered. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0445	9	1053	1268	- 25: Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, says the protest movement seeks to topple the Communist Party -- a claim that forms the basis of an explosive editorial in the official People's Daily newspaper the next day. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0445	10	1278	1428	- 27: Huge student demonstrations take place in Beijing, and protests erupt across the country, including in towns that had been calm until that time. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0445	11	1438	1441	May 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0445	12	1451	1580	- 4: The anniversary of the patriotic movement of May 4, 1919 triggers a new mass demonstration in Beijing and in 50 other towns.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0445	20	2267	2300	It is his last public appearance.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	0	58	91	Key dates in post-Tiananmen China 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	1	166	319	The following is a list of key dates in the history of China, following the crushing of the Tiananmen pro-democracy protests by army troops in June 1989: 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	2	329	333	1989 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	3	343	517	After 10 years of market reform and opening to the outside world, China finds itself again isolated internationally and the target of sanctions after the Tiananmen crackdown. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	4	518	628	Arms embargoes by the United States and the European Union are implemented and remain in place 20 years later. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	5	638	642	1990 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	6	652	766	Deng Xiaoping formally retires from all of his official positions, but remains influential from behind the scenes. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	7	776	780	1992

AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	9	910	1044	The government calls for students staying overseas to return to China no matter what their attitude on past political events has been. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0446	10	1054	1058	1993

AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	0	58	90	Tiananmen Square: 10 key figures 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	1	165	340	The following are brief profiles of the 10 people -- students, politicians and others -- who played key roles in the drama that unfolded in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in 1989: 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	2	350	362	THE STUDENTS 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	3	372	410	-- Wang Dan, the moderate (born 1969). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	4	411	524	A student from the elite Peking University, he was replaced as leader of the movement by more radical protesters. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	5	525	603	After his arrest in July 1989, he was sentenced in 1991 to four years in jail. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	6	604	722	He was released in 1993, but arrested again in 1995 on subversion charges and sentenced to another 11 years in prison. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	7	723	769	In 1998, he was deported to the United States. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	8	770	831	He continues his campaign for democracy in China in the west. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	9	841	876	-- Chai Ling, the muse (born 1966). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	10	877	977	The tiny woman was known as the "general commander" of the protest headquarters at Tiananmen Square. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	11	978	1118	After the crackdown, she was put on the list of the 21 most wanted students, but after 10 months on the run she managed to escape to France. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	12	1119	1199	She now lives in the United States, where she works as an Internet entrepreneur. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	13	1209	1247	-- Wu'er Kaixi, the rebel (born 1968). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	14	1248	1461	A member of the Uighur ethnic minority, he became a celebrity overnight after he interrupted Premier Li Peng during a meeting between student leaders and politicians aired live on state television on May 18, 1989. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	15	1462	1539	He was able to flee China after the June 4 crackdown and now lives in Taiwan. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	16	1549	1564	THE POLITICIANS 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	17	1574	1618	-- Deng Xiaoping, the patriarch (1904-1997). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	18	1619	1883	The most influential of the leaders, the chairman of the Central Military Commission and father of economic reform tilted the balance in favour of a hard line and ordered the army to fire on protesters after six weeks of rallies that left the government paralysed. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	19	1893	1944	-- Zhao Ziyang, the disgraced reformer (1919-2005). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	20	1945	2054	As general secretary of the Communist Party, he supported dialogue between the government and the protesters. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	21	2055	2152	On May 19, 1989, he visited the students on Tiananmen Square, and, in tears, urged them to leave. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	22	2153	2189	This was his last public appearance. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	23	2190	2274	He was relieved of his duties in June and placed under house arrest until his death. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	24	2284	2322	-- Li Peng, the hardliner (born 1928). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	25	2323	2476	He was made prime minister in 1988 and also a member of the Standing Committee of the Communist Party's Politburo, the heart of political power in China. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	26	2477	2546	Announcing martial law on May 19, he paved the way for the crackdown. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	27	2556	2573	THE INTELLECTUALS 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	28	2583	2632	-- Fang Lizhi, the veteran dissident (born 1936). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	29	2633	2759	Even if this famous astrophysicist did not participate directly in the Tiananmen movement, his ideas were a clear inspiration. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	30	2760	2907	He had been thrown out of the Communist Party in 1987, and shortly after the crackdown in 1989, the authorities issued an arrest order against him. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	31	2908	3002	He escaped into the US embassy, and was granted political asylum in the United States in 1991. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	32	3012	3052	-- Liu Xiaobo, the mediator (born 1955). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	33	3053	3212	The author was popular among the young for his criticism of traditional Chinese values, and further joined the students in a hunger strike on Tiananmen Square. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	34	3213	3363	On the night of June 3 and into the early hours of June 4, as the army proceeded to clear the square, he attempted to negotiate an orderly evacuation. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	35	3364	3460	He was later arrested and spent a year and a half in jail without ever being formally sentenced. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	36	3470	3480	THE ARTIST 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	37	3490	3526	-- Cui Jian, the rocker (born 1961). 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	38	3527	3710	The "father of rock" in China appeared several times on Tiananmen Square in 1989, and one of his works, "Nothing to My Name", became the unofficial fight song of the student movement. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	39	3720	3736	THE UNKNOWN HERO 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	40	3746	3932	-- On June 5, the day after the crackdown, a young man placed himself in front of a column of tanks, preventing it from passing down the Avenue of Heavenly Peace in the heart of Beijing. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	41	3933	4043	At one point he even mounted the front tank to appeal to its crew, but bystanders eventually dragged him away. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	42	4044	4232	Photos and footage of the "Tank Man" immediately made top news around the world, and he went down in history as a symbol of peaceful and unarmed protesters confronting military repression. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0447	43	4233	4270	His name remains unknown to this day. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	0	58	94	China faces dark memory of Tiananmen 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	1	169	351	Authorities in China are bracing for the 20th anniversary of the deadly June 4 crackdown on pro-democracy protests in Tiananmen Square, a pivotal moment that still haunts the nation. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	2	361	591	The way the government will likely mark the sensitive date on Thursday -- with deafening silence -- shows it is keenly aware of the emotional scars that remain after the army ended six weeks of peaceful rallies in central Beijing. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	3	601	832	China's Communist leaders have made any discussion of the brutal quelling of the student-led demonstrations -- in which hundreds, maybe thousands, were killed -- taboo, but dissidents say the public could yet hold them accountable. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	4	842	1053	"People remember this date because they want the Communist Party to take responsibility for the crimes it committed," said 53-year-old Qi Zhiyong, who lost a leg after being shot by troops near Tiananmen Square. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	5	1063	1154	"It reminds them the party will resort to unbridled violence whenever it feels threatened." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	6	1164	1284	In a bid not to rankle the wary authorities, the main public commemoration planned for Thursday will probably be silent. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	7	1294	1500	Activist groups have called on citizens simply to wear white -- the traditional colour of mourning -- to honour those killed in the mayhem that erupted when tanks and troops rolled in to crush the protests. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	8	1510	1734	The year 1989 was a disastrous one for communism across the globe and in China the ruling party found itself in a struggle with democracy activists who challenged its authoritarian rule over the world's most populous nation. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	9	1744	1975	The Tiananmen movement began in mid-April, when public grief over the death of former party leader and popular reformer Hu Yaobang gradually morphed into bold calls from students for political reform and steps to combat corruption. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	10	1985	2084	Young students started to occupy Tiananmen Square, the symbolic centre of political power in China. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	11	2085	2208	A sense of euphoria saturated the plaza as they took part in rallies no one would have thought possible just weeks earlier. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	12	2218	2249	"There were banners everywhere. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	13	2250	2405	This was the first unauthorised political demonstration in the (history of the) People's Republic of China," recalled one of the student leaders, Wang Dan. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	14	2415	2630	Calls for democracy and freedom filled the square, thousands went on hunger strike, and one charismatic activist, Wu'er Kaixi, brazenly challenged Premier Li Peng during a meeting broadcast live on state television. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	15	2640	2868	Indeed, the whole world was watching, as news crews from around the globe gathered in Beijing to cover the historic visit by then Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev, only to stumble upon an event that would be far more significant. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	16	2878	3045	In the corridors of power, the protests drove a wedge between hardline leaders led by Premier Li and moderates headed by Communist Party general secretary Zhao Ziyang. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	17	3055	3168	The hardliners won, with patriarch Deng Xiaoping, China's most powerful man, tilting the balance in their favour. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	18	3169	3278	Zhao was removed from his post as party leader and spent 16 years under house arrest until his death in 2005. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	19	3288	3484	The student movement was declared a "counterrevolutionary rebellion", and soldiers of the People's Liberation Army descended on the capital, crushing the democratic dreams of an entire generation. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	20	3494	3565	The number of people killed in the night of June 3-4 remains a mystery. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	21	3566	3624	China's official death toll is 241, including 36 students. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	22	3625	3664	Dissidents say thousands may have died. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	23	3674	3871	The crackdown set off a wave of condemnation across the globe, and for several years China was treated as a near-pariah, as Western governments offered asylum to student leaders fleeing into exile. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	24	3881	4089	The international community has long since welcomed China back into the fold, and Beijing's communist leaders have cemented their hold on power, transforming the country into the world's number three economy. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	25	4099	4269	But they have shown no willingness to change their position that the protests threatened Communist Party rule and had to be quelled in order to maintain economic reforms. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	26	4279	4475	"Facts have proven that the socialist road with Chinese characteristics that we pursue is in the fundamental interests of our people," foreign ministry spokesman Ma Zhaoxu told journalists in May. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	27	4485	4708	But, undeterred, victims of the crackdown have called for renewed international pressure on Beijing to reverse the official verdict on the quelling, saying failure to stand up to a rising China tacitly abets the repression. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	28	4718	4892	"So far, the international community... has adopted a policy of appeasement towards the Chinese government," said Ding Zilin, 72, whose teenage son was shot dead by the army. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	29	4902	5125	Bao Tong -- a former aide to Zhao who was jailed for seven years following the crackdown -- said the world has failed to push China to be more open about the events of Tiananmen because of Beijing's increasing global clout. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	30	5135	5347	"Not wanting to offend China means they cannot help China, cannot help China's people attain their own rights, and cannot help the world community gain a reliable, stable, peaceful member," Bao told AFP recently. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	31	5357	5394	"This is not a good thing," he added. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0448	32	5404	5619	Bao has since been ordered to sit out the anniversary at a resort more than 1,000 kilometres (625 miles) from Beijing -- evidence that the authorities in the capital are not yet ready to reopen the Tiananmen wounds. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0449	0	58	102	Tiananmen, 20 years on -- a special advisory 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0449	1	173	278	Twenty years ago, China's military crushed peaceful pro-democracy protests in Beijing's Tiananmen Square. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0449	2	279	338	Hundreds, perhaps thousands, were killed on June 3-4, 1989.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	0	58	103	US urges rejection of Guantanamo Uighurs case 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	1	208	402	President Barack Obama's administration has asked the Supreme Court to reject a request by Chinese Uighurs held at the Guantanamo Bay prison and cleared of all charges to be released on US soil. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	2	412	458	The petitioners "have already obtained relief. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	3	459	613	They are no longer being detained as enemy combatants," wrote US Solicitor General Elena Kagan in the administration's filing to the Supreme Court Friday. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	4	623	862	Kagan wrote that the men, members of a Turkic-speaking Muslim minority who fear persecution if returned to China, "are being housed in relatively unrestricted conditions given the status of Guantanamo Bay as a United States military base." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	5	872	1110	Four years ago US authorities cleared the 17 imprisoned Uighurs, but they are stuck at the Guantanamo prison due to fears that Beijing would torture them if they returned to their homeland in northwestern China's remote Xinjiang province. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	6	1120	1223	At the prison, the Uighurs are held at "Camp Iguana," a special area for detainees cleared for release. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	7	1224	1369	They have more freedom and greater privileges than most other prisoners, including a recreational space and a library, according to the Pentagon. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	8	1379	1469	In October 2008 a federal judge ordered that the Uighurs be released in the United States. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	9	1470	1639	The most likely place for the detainees to be released would be in Washington's suburbs in northern Virginia, which is home to a significant Uighur expatriate community. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	10	1649	1716	A federal appeals court in February however overturned that ruling. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	11	1717	1800	It is the Uighurs' appeal to that decision that the Supreme Court must now address. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	12	1810	1915	But for the Obama administration, which is repeating some of the reasoning that his predecessor George W. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	13	1916	2125	Bush used, "the decision whether to allow aliens abroad to enter the United States and if so, under what terms, rests exclusively in the political branches," according to the filing, which AFP obtained a copy. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	14	2135	2474	For the government, the "petitioners' continued presence at Guantanamo Bay is not unlawful detention but rather the consequence of their lawful exclusion from the United States under the constitutional exercise of authority by the political branches, coupled with the unavailability of another country willing to accept them," Kagan wrote. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	15	2484	2646	The nine justices sitting on the US high court have not yet said whether they would examine the politically explosive case, and could announce a decision by June. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	16	2656	2714	The legal case was filed by 14 of the 17 Uighur prisoners. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	17	2724	2839	The Guantanamo camp was established by the Bush administration as an offshore prison for "war on terror" detainees. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	18	2840	2929	Some 800 youth and adults have passed through the prison camp and about 240 remain today. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	19	2939	3090	The US navy established a base in Guantanamo Bay at the end of the 1898 Spanish- American War, then signed a long-term lease with the Cuban government. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0450	20	3091	3165	Cuba's communist government has been demanding its return since the 1960s.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	3	630	834	US officials could not even rule out the possibility of Clinton's skipping the OAS meeting altogether if negotiators fail to agree on terms for bringing Cuba back within the 35-member organization's fold. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	4	844	1065	The United States wants Cuba to free political prisoners and respect political freedoms for it to participate fully in the OAS, saying it is holding the body to the democratic principles enshrined in its own 2001 charter. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0453	5	1075	1158	Other OAS members say that Cuba can be nudged toward democracy once inside the OAS.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0457	1	171	374	Cricket's newest format returns to its birthplace when England hosts the World Twenty20 from Friday with the event kicking off a bumper summer which includes one of the sport's oldest combats, the Ashes. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0457	2	384	567	But, as with all the other forms of one-day cricket first played in England at county level, the 'mother country' has found herself having to play catch-up with the rest of the world. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0457	3	577	761	Originally conceived as a fun way of bringing new audiences, particularly those who couldn't watch cricket during the working day, into the game, Twenty20 has taken the sport by storm. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0457	4	771	939	Tournaments such as the Indian Premier League (IPL) are now far more lucrative per match for a player than five-day Test cricket, the traditional pinnacle of the sport. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0457	5	949	1144	India, whose administrators were originally hostile to Twenty20 because they feared its commercial impact upon the 50-over game, won the inaugural global tournament in South Africa two years ago.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0463	1	172	356	Pace spearhead Umar Gul insists he will not curb his aggressive style of bowling during the World Twenty20, saying his wicket-taking ability is key if Pakistan are to clinch the title. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0463	2	366	511	The 25-year-old, who is the leading wicket-taker in the newest form of the game with 24 victims in 14 matches, is in the best form of his career. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0463	3	521	746	The lanky Peshawar-born paceman boasts a career-best 4-8 - the second best performance in T20 internationals behind New Zealand’s Mark Gillespie’s 4-7 against Kenya in 2007 - which helped Pakistan beat Australia in Dubai. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0463	4	756	985	"I want to do better than the last time," said Gul, who finished as the leading wicket-taker with 13 in seven matches to anchor Pakistan’s runners-up finish to India in the inaugural World Twenty20 held in South Africa in 2007. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0463	5	995	1069	Gul said he sees the batsman-oriented Twenty20 cricket as a big challenge. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0463	6	1079	1233	"Bowling in Twenty20 is a great challenge, but I am always up for it and I believe in attacking the batsmen from the first delivery to the last," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0463	7	1243	1377	Gul will be spearheading an attack which includes fast maturing Sohail Tanvir, Rao Iftikhar, Yasir Arafat and newcomer Mohammad Aamir. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0463	8	1387	1539	The line-up looks inexperienced after Shoaib Akhtar was withdrawn due to injury and with Mohammad Asif still absent because of a one-year ban on doping. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0463	9	1549	1614	But Gul is confident Pakistan can still bowl their opponents out. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0463	10	1624	1824	"We have a balanced attack and if we bowl to a tight line and length, then we can get teams out or restrict them to gettable totals," said Gul, who prefers to come as first-change in Twenty20 matches. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0463	11	1834	1963	"Coming on first change helps you get more swing and it’s the ideal time to not only stop the flow of runs but to take wickets. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0463	12	1973	2144	"We came so close to winning the title in 2007 but it was bad luck," added Gul, whose three wickets restricted India to 157-5 in the final in the inaugural World Twenty20. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0463	13	2154	2210	"This time round we want to finish it without a blemish. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0463	14	2211	2248	The title, nothing less, is the aim." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0464	0	58	108	Cricket: England get set for Twenty20 without Fred 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0464	1	182	359	England have never won a major international one-day tournament and, even allowing for home advantage, it will be a major surprise if they come out on top in the World Twenty20. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0464	2	369	578	English one-day cricket has generally been based on the idea of the steady accumulation of runs, followed by a dash at the finish, and steady, containing bowling by medium-pacers who 'do a job' for their side. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0464	3	588	840	What recent tournaments have shown is the need for wicket-taking bowlers in an era where economy rates are of limited value, given how aggressive modern batsmen are, and batsmen capable of scoring quickly, particularly in the early overs of an innings. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0464	4	850	1072	The loss through a knee injury of all-rounder Andrew Flintoff, a dynamic seamer with an ability to get reverse swing and, on his day, a hard-hitting batsman, would appear to have robbed the hosts of a genuine match-winner. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0464	5	1082	1269	Meanwhile, star batsman Kevin Pietersen's Achilles injury, which ruled the South Africa-born shotmaker out of the recent homne one-day series with the West Indies, also remains a concern. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0464	6	1279	1405	However, albeit in a 50-over format and against opponents who didn't seem too keen to be on tour, England won that series 2-0. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0464	7	1415	1576	And emerging England quick Stuart Broad, himself a handy lower order batsman, believes that Flintoff's absence need not spell the end of England's victory hopes. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0464	8	1586	1691	"We've certainly won well without Fred in the past, but it's important we play good cricket," Broad said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0464	9	1701	1852	"He's obviously a very important player for us with bat and ball but players step up and take responsibility when he's not here, that's very important. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0464	10	1862	2001	"We need to gain confidence of winning without Fred so when he comes back into the side there will be a lot of belief and confidence there. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0464	11	2011	2179	"Fred is the sort of bowler who gets thrown the ball in an important situation but when he's not in the side someone else gets given the ball and takes responsibility." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0464	12	2189	2390	But apart from three wins over New Zealand last year, England have not beaten a major nation in Twenty20 cricket since levelling their two match series against the West Indies at The Oval in June 2007. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0464	13	2400	2568	England's only win at the inaugural World Twenty20 in South Africa a few months later was against Zimbabwe, with the side losing to South Africa, New Zealand and India. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0464	14	2578	2754	However, England's squad does now contain players with plenty of domestic Twenty20 experience in Hampshire all-rounder Dimitri Mascarenhas and Essex wicket-keeper James Foster. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0464	15	2764	3024	And England coach Andy Flower believes Ravi Bopara can provide the solution to the side's longtstanding problems at the top of the order in one-day cricket which have been an issue since the international retirement of Somerset left- hander Marcus Trescothick. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0464	16	3034	3172	"You must be able to adapt, have strong hitters and top-class batsmen up front," Flower said in an interview with the Big Hitter magazine. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0464	17	3182	3336	"Ravi Bopara has shown what a class player can do at the top of the order, which you need against the new ball - not just lower order sloggers thrown in." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0464	18	3346	3541	England captain Andrew Strauss is sitting out this tournament on the grounds that he does not believe himself to be a good enough Twenty20 player, with the leadership passing to Paul Collingwood. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0464	19	3551	3628	"I don't think it (Strauss's authority) will be diluted at all," Flower said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0464	20	3638	3724	"I still think ideally you would want one captain for all forms but that wasn't to be. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0464	21	3725	3776	We've just got to make the best of that situation."

AFP_ENG_20090531.0467	0	58	110	Cricket: Gloveman McCullum holds key for New Zealand 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0467	1	188	380	The weight of New Zealand's Twenty20 World Cup expectations rests heavily on the shoulders of Brendon McCullum and his burning desire to be recognised as the world's best wicketkeeper-batsman. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0467	2	390	564	The diminutive gloveman is the key element in New Zealand's game plan with his audacious batting at the top of the order and his lightning-fast reactions behind the woodwork. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0467	3	574	724	That the 27-year-old's name is often mentioned as a contender to inherit the mantle of Australian great Adam Gilchrist speaks volumes for his ability. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0467	4	734	908	In the Indian Premier League, the Kolkata Knight Riders valued McCullum at 700,000 US dollars, the biggest offer for a New Zealand player, when they snapped him up last year. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0467	5	918	1115	They were immediately rewarded when he launched the inaugural IPL series by smashing a record 158 off 73 balls and he ended the season with an average 62.66 with the bat at a strike rate of 204.35. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0467	6	1125	1325	New Zealand's 2008 Player of the Year has also won high praise from Australia where a cameo McCullum performance helped New South Wales qualify for the Champions League Twenty20 tournament in October. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0467	7	1335	1500	"There is no doubt having Brendon McCullum in your team increases your chances of a win, that is an undeniable fact," said Cricket NSW chief executive David Gilbert. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0467	8	1510	1703	In the just-completed second IPL series leading up to the World Twenty20, McCullum's batting was below par by his usual standards, finishing with an average of 23.75 at a strike rate of 119.24. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0467	9	1713	1857	But ominiously, McCullum was working his way into form as the World Twenty20 approached with two knocks in the 80s in his last four IPL innings. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0467	10	1867	2080	In a side which struggles for consistancy, much is made of whether McCullum's best role with the bat is as a blockbusting opener or an aggressive middle-order hitter who can get New Zealand across the finish line. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0467	11	2090	2190	Coach Andy Moles is adamant he will lead with McCullum in partnership with the emerging Jesse Ryder. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0467	12	2200	2367	"Opening is Brendon's place," he said with memories still fresh of the way McCullum engineered a clean sweep over India in their Twenty20 two-match series in February. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0467	13	2377	2531	McCullum carried his bat through both innings and in a dramatic finish to the second game he calmly stroked a single off the final ball to secure the win. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0467	14	2541	2729	New Zealand will rely on that same McCullum calmness to get them through the World Twenty20, while the gloveman will be looking to enhance his own reputation as well as aiding his country. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0467	15	2739	2823	"I want to be the best batsman-keeper in the world," he told the New Zealand Herald. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0468	0	58	111	Cricket: Warner exclusively made for T20 pyrotechnics 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0468	1	185	293	Australia's man in a hurry David Warner can be grateful for the explosion in popularity of Twenty20 cricket. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0468	2	303	477	It seems the diminutive opening left-hander and T20 are a natural fit, such has been his extraordinary entry and impact on the stand-and-deliver form of the abbreviated game. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0468	3	487	716	Warner, 22, this year became the first player in 132 years to debut for Australia without playing first-class cricket, such was his prodigious reputation after clubbing a one-day record knock of 165 for his state New South Wales. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0468	4	726	970	Although not considered good enough to play Sheffield Shield cricket for NSW, he ripped into the South African bowling on his international Twenty20  debut, peeling off a rollicking 89 off 43 balls at the Melbourne Cricket Ground on January 11. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0468	5	980	1207	Warner smashed seven fours and six sixes in his all-action innings to finish just 11 runs short of becoming only the second player after Chris Gayle to score a Twenty20 International century in his man-of-the-match performance. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0468	6	1217	1320	Skipper Ricky Ponting compares Warner's rumbustious hitting with former master- blaster Adam Gilchrist. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0468	7	1330	1463	"He hit some huge sixes tonight when I was out there, it was some of the sweetest hitting I've seen," Ponting said of Warner's cameo. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0468	8	1464	1505	"It was like having 'Gilly' there again." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0468	9	1515	1618	His new-won fame earned an IPL contract with Delhi Daredevils and a deal to use a unique two-sided bat. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0468	10	1619	1694	Warner hit 163 runs off 132 balls faced in seven knocks for the Daredevils. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0468	11	1704	1833	As the short-game batting sensation heads to the World Twenty20 he has racked up 177 runs in five innings for Australia at 35.40. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0468	12	1843	2044	Warner has been described as pure cricket box-office and has developed an aggressive switch hitting style where he often uses the back of his bat or takes a right-handed stance to go after the bowling. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0468	13	2054	2192	He generates enormous power from his strong forearms and uses his small stature to get underneath deliveries and hit them high in the air. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0468	14	2202	2349	In one T20 match for his state this year, he smoked a six off express bowler Shaun Tait that landed on the roof of one of the Adelaide Oval stands. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0468	15	2359	2465	"It's not like I'm trying to hit every ball into the next suburb," Warner says of his pyrotechnic batting. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0468	16	2466	2525	"Basically, if it's in my area, I'm not going to hold back. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0468	17	2535	2615	"If it's ball one or the last ball of the day, I'm still not going to hold back. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0468	18	2616	2694	I know when to be more careful, but basically, I want to score off every ball. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0468	19	2704	2732	"I just have to back myself. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0468	20	2733	2821	You get a good start and the crowd starts going and you want to keep going on the roll." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	0	58	113	Cricket: Unorthodox Van der Merwe adds punch to Proteas 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	1	193	416	He’s an unlikely cricket star - a short, stocky all-rounder with a mediocre first-class record - but Roelof van der Merwe has become a Twenty20 player to be reckoned with since he made his debut for South Africa in March. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	2	426	620	Van der Merwe’s nickname with his Titans franchise is 'Bulldog' and he lives up to it with his aggressive attitude as a left-arm slow bowler, hard-hitting right-handed batsman or in the field. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	3	630	852	Selected for the South African under-19 team in 2004, his cricket career seemed to hit a dead end and he admits he spent more time partying than working on his game in his first year or so after leaving school in Pretoria. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	4	862	1090	He started attracting serious attention in the 2007/08 season with his economical bowling and effective pinch-hitting for the Titans in limited overs cricket, helping the franchise win both the 45-overs and 20-overs competition. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	5	1100	1229	On Twenty20 international debut he top-scored with 48 against Australia with a frenzied mixture of wild hits and judicious bunts. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	6	1239	1361	He swung his bat with such ferocity that one attempted pull shot flew off a top edge over point for one of his four sixes. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	7	1371	1567	Drafted into the South African one-day international side, he topped his side’s bowling averages and was the most economical bowler, twice taking three wickets in an innings in four appearances. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	8	1577	1715	Snapped up by the Royal Challengers Bangalore, he became a regular member of the team that reached the final of the Indian Premier League. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	9	1725	1786	While his batting appears agricultural, his bowling is canny. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	10	1796	1936	He bowls with tight control and his franchise coach Richard Pybus said: "He has an instinct for anticipating what a batsman is going to do." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	11	1946	2014	South African captain Graeme Smith likes Van der Merwe’s attitude. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	12	2024	2127	"He really wants to be an active part of the game which, when you come in as a youngster, is important. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	13	2128	2184	If you’re a bit sheepish then the game will test you." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	14	2194	2244	No-one can accuse Van der Merwe of being sheepish.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	16	2368	2423	And he’s unbowed when teased about his batting style. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0469	17	2433	2575	"It’s not how you drive, it’s how you arrive," he said when presented with the man of the match award in his first Twenty20 international.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0472	13	2128	2184	If you’re a bit sheepish then the game will test you." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0472	14	2194	2244	No-one can accuse Van der Merwe of being sheepish.

AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	0	58	107	Cricket: Hamilton looks to restore Scottish pride 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	1	181	347	Scotland captain Gavin Hamilton hopes the World Twenty20 will enable his side to get back on track following their surprise failure to qualify for the 2011 World Cup. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	2	357	564	Long one of the most consistent nations outside the Test elite, a run of poor results during the recent 2011 qualifying tournament in South Africa saw Scotland fail to make it to the showpiece event in Asia. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	3	574	805	Ryan Watson was stripped of the captaincy and in his place came all-rounder Hamilton, whose one and only Test appearance a decade ago for England saw him fail to take a wicket and record a pair against South Africa in Johannesburg. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	4	815	985	Now 34, Hamilton's career in England was to suffer dramatically when a move from Yorkshire to Durham saw him get what golfers would term the 'yips' with his seam bowling. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	5	995	1182	But he has been able to continue his Scotland career and now Hamilton hopes a new-look side can give a good account of themselves in a Group D also featuring South Africa and New Zealand. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	6	1192	1366	"We're realistic about our chances of winning games, but if there's ever a game to win, it's Twenty20 because the whole thing can turn around in two or three overs," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	7	1376	1467	"It's a case of having people playing well and hopefully catching teams on a semi-bad day." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	8	1477	1624	Scotland face England in a warm-up match on Tuesday at Trent Bridge but Hamilton said his 1999 experience would not be something he would dwell on. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	9	1634	1670	"That was a long time ago," he said. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	10	1671	1747	"I had my ups and downs thinking about that in the couple of years after it. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	11	1748	1760	But not now. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0473	12	1770	1862	"It was an experience I'd like to change but I came away from that tour a better cricketer."

AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	0	58	101	Cricket: Broad looking for better headlines 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	1	175	321	England quick Stuart Broad goes into the World Twenty20 determined to make the most of a tournament often seen as a hiding to nothing for bowlers. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	2	331	468	Broad, at 22 an improving paceman and a more than handy lower order batsman, is quickly becoming an important member of the England team. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	3	478	821	But it says something about the self-belief of the son of former England opening batsman Chris that his confidence was not dented permanently when, during the corresponding tournament in South Africa two years ago, he became the first bowler to be hit for six sixes in an over during a Twenty20 international by India's Yuvraj Singh in Durban. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	4	831	864	"Anyone can get hit," said Broad. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	5	865	942	"You can see that in the amount of Twenty20 cricket that is being played now. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	6	952	1046	"They bring the boundaries in, they make it smaller and everyone wants to see fours and sixes. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	7	1047	1135	So, as a bowler, you've got to accept sometimes you're going to be on the receiving end. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	8	1145	1281	"The important thing is how you bounce back, how you improve as a bowler and how you learn new deliveries and practice different skills. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	9	1291	1411	"It's important, certainly at a young age, to learn from it, take it in your stride and turn everything into a positive. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	10	1421	1534	"It was a chance to really improve me as a bowler and I couldn't be happier with the way the last year has gone." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	11	1544	1663	England were off the pace in South Africa, failing to beat a major nation during a run of just one win in five matches. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	12	1673	1821	But they will have home advantage on their side in a group that sees them take on Pakistan, losing finalists in 2007, and outsiders the Netherlands. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	13	1831	1896	"I think hosting the event is a massive plus for us," said Broad. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	14	1897	2037	"Twenty20 is really big in England on the domestic side so to be having the World Twenty20 is going to make the crowds even more excitable." 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	15	2047	2251	And while Andrew Flintoff's latest injury, a knee problem, has ruled the star all-rounder out of the tournament, Broad said it was time England stopped despairing when confronted with life without 'Fred'. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	16	2261	2364	"When he's not in the side someone else gets given the ball and takes responsibility," Broad explained. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	17	2374	2454	"I thrive on that extra responsibility and I certainly like taking the new ball. 
AFP_ENG_20090531.0475	18	2455	2544	We talk about the first 10 overs setting the tone and that's my job with Jimmy Anderson."
